# Chapter 24

Quinn

-----

“How much further is it to the University,” I asked.

We’d already been walking for ten or fifteen minutes since leaving the obelisk that served as Nimre’s teleport beacon.

“When? We’re here Quinn, the beacon was just inside the front gates. All of this around us is the university,” he said, and I could hear the smile in his voice.

*Holy shit. This place is huge.*

“Wow, I’m sure this would all be super impressive if I could see any of it,” I said, “How big is this place? I think Ventia might have even been smaller.”

“Almost. There’s usually about thirty thousand students at the university at any given time, add on the instructors and all the little shops that serve the university and I think you end up with something like forty thousand people living just within the university quarter. Ventia has over fifty thousand people living in it, so it’s close.”

*It’s only about a half the size of U of T, but U of T has got all of Toronto and a modern transit system to feed it.*

“Damn, what about the rest of the city? Aren’t there other universities and schools here in Nimre?” I asked.

“Not sure about the rest of the city, I think it’s about another forty thousand people. I honestly never really left the university much. Nimre isn’t too bad, but there’s still some resentment towards Mages that come down from the university and start ‘making trouble’.”

“Yeah, I think I can understand that.”

*Drunk college students with super powers? Yeah, I can see how that would be a problem.*

“I mean, it’s not too terrible. The city has the power it has and is as rich as it is because of the presence of the university, but… it’s complicated. I might not be the Mage to ask about this sort of thing, but there’s a bit of fear of the unknown, bit of jealousy, and all it takes is for one student to make a mess to piss off all the ‘normal’ folk.”

“Ha, and I’m guessing that the average student Mage can make one hell of a mess.”

“Oh Hala,” he said, putting a hand to his forehead, “The Order of the Claves…”

“The Order of the what?” I asked, confused.

“They’re one of the university’s major guilds. They’re known for their little ‘jests’. I think their members are still probably banned from most of the lower city after the whole mess with the Font of Endless Custard.”

*Font of Endless… Well I guess magical matter creation is a possibility.*

I was about to ask him to elaborate, but it seemed that we’d arrived.

“Here we are,” he said, indicating the truly massive building that we’d stopped in front of, “This is the Arena. You might be spending a lot of time here, depending on how much you focus on combat magic.”

He lead the way inside, and I what I could see of it reminded very much of the Colosseum in Rome. The building must have risen about fifty metres in the air, and it had the same multi-tiered set of arches all the way around the rim of it.

“Your instructors will probably take you here to practice safely, and you can even take part in tournaments and melees if you’re feeling a little competitive.”

“Safely? So I could, I don’t know, throw a lightning bolt at someone, and it wouldn’t hurt them?”

“Well, see for yourself,” he said, as we came out into open air.

We were at ground level, and the seats rose in tiers behind me. There was a short wall in front of me, then a drop of about three metres to the actual floor of the Arena. There were very few spectators present, with only the occasional splotch of colour against the grey stone to mark where someone sat. Even standing at the very edge, it was hard to make out the figures fighting. One was large, very large for an elf. He must have been about close to my height, but he was built thickly enough to make the Rock look small. The other was slight of build, and at this distance I couldn’t tell if they were man or woman. Elf men seemed to keep their hair about as long as elf women, though the smaller figure did have theirs in a ponytail which was the style that elf men seemed to favour.

This being a magical contest, I was expecting the smaller figure to blast the huge one into the nearest wall in short order. After all, Strength is a dump stat for a proper spellcaster. They stand at the back of the party and fling fireballs, they didn’t waste time lifting weights. The big man might have a chance if he could get in close, but any proper Mage wasn’t about to allow that to happen.

The smaller figure shouted a word, and there was a crack of thunder. A bolt of lightning streaked from their outstretched hand, but the blinding blue-white light stopped about a foot from the hulking Mage. It seemed to strike an invisible wall and then ground itself out in the hard-packed sand of the arena. The hulking Mage said nothing, and instead he threw both hands forwards. Twin bolts of fire streaked towards the smaller Mage, who snapped out a short word and made a slight gesture. The bolts of fire seemed to veer slightly off course, and they both passed harmlessly to either side.

The two bolts were maybe a foot behind the smaller Mage when they both exploded with a loud ‘WHOOMPFF’. Even at this distance I could feel the pressure wave hit my chest, and the smaller mage was thrown forwards, hair and clothes aflame. He landed face first, and I could see that his back was charred black, and his arms were little better than burnt sticks.

*Holy fuck!*

“Holy fuck!” I exclaimed, “Is he dead?”

“No no, don’t worry. He’ll be back on his feet in a minute or two. The magic of the Arena is designed specifically for this sort of thing. Clothes, anything you bring along, those can get damaged or destroyed, but people aren’t actually hurt.”

*So it’s like a magical Danger Room. Danger Arena?*

“It feels like it hurts though, so it’s still best to avoid getting blown up or decapitated.”

“Decapitated? What?”

“Barely ever happens,” he said, laughing and patting me on the shoulder, “But the Arena will protect you even from that. Come on, we’ve got to meet Lili.”

He led the way back through the tunnel, and I continued my line of questioning, “How does it work? It seems like you’d want to just blanket the whole city with an enchantment like that. I bet it would cut down on murders by about one hundred percent.”

“I’m the wrong sort to ask for specifics, but I’m fairly sure that the Arena only works like it does because of the ley line nexus below it. That’s used to power some sort of planar enchantment. I never really studied that sort of thing much, but I don’t think that the enchantment could be sustained without such a large source of power.”

*Ley lines, planar enchantments? I think I’m going to have fun here.*

“Planar, so the Arena is in a different plane of existence?” I asked.

“Sort of, I think? The area within the walls at least. All I know is that the ‘rules’ are different when you’re standing in the pit. Whichever Mages built the Arena found a plane where people couldn’t be hurt permanently or where magic worked a little different, and then used the nexus to make a little bubble so they could practice and fight there.”

*So there’s different planes of existence, and some have different laws of physics. Hold on, are this world’s laws of physics different from Earth’s? I mean, the presence of magic does seem to suggest that there’s something funky going on.*

I had so many questions, but it felt like I didn’t know enough to make sense of the answers, so I stuck to what I could understand.

“Who were those two in the Arena?” I asked.

“The elf I’m not sure about, but I’ve heard about that living mountain, even out as far as Ashur. That’s Nothus, probably the single most talented, and most powerful Mage currently studying in the university.”

*Note to self, befriend Nothus as soon as possible.*

-----

Waenne led me to a large, low building that seemed to share a lot with some of the older buildings at the University of Toronto. It wasn’t quite Queen Anne architecture, but it was very close. We went inside, and climbed the stairs to the third floor where Waenne told me that many of the instructors had their offices. Thankfully the ceilings here weren’t too low, and I could just barely stand up straight. I followed Waenne to a slightly open door, and he knocked lightly on the doorframe before poking his head in.

“Waenne!” Said a woman’s voice,  “I haven’t seen you in ages. I’m surprised Cilla let you out of the house. What’s the occasion?”

Waenne sighed, “You know it’s not like that, Lili. I-“

“Isn’t it?” Lili taunted.

Waenne tilted his head to the side, and I was sure that he was giving her a look, “I’ve got a new student for you.”

He stepped into the room, and waved me forwards, “Say hello, Quinn.”

I stepped into the small room, and could at least make out the general details. The wall behind the desk was covered by several well-ordered bookshelves, there was a large window on the far wall, and there were a few art pieces hanging from the other two. At the desk sat a small woman, she seemed small even for an elf, and she wore what looked like long blue robes. She had long gold hair, and big blue eyes. Her robes were closed, but I could see that they swelled out fairly generously around the bust area. I could see why Cillia was a little possessive, even half blind I could see that Lili was a bombshell.

“Hello Quinn,” I said.

Waenne sighed, but Lili pushed her chair back, and came around to the front of her desk.

“Nice to meet you Quinn,” she said, extending a hand.

“Uh,” I hesitated, then I extended my own hand, “Here?”

She seemed a little confused, but grasped my hand. Hers was tiny compared to mine, her middle finger was even smaller than my little finger.

“Oh? Oh.” She said, looking down. She took my hand in both of hers, turning it over, “Can you feel anything at all?” She asked, tracing her fingers over my palm.

“Nope. Everything up to the elbows might as well be made of wood,” I said flatly.

She looked to Waenne, “The manacles were on, and active for at least a full day before I removed them,” he said, seeming almost guilty, despite the fact that what happened to me wasn’t his fault.

“You poor thing,” she soothed, and I pulled my hand back.

*Not pity. Never pity.*

“I can manage,” I said, trying not to snap at her.

“I’m sorry,” she said, “I didn’t mean to offend.”

“It’s fine,” I said quietly.

There was an awkward silence, before Waenne spoke up, “Well Lili, I thought it might be best if I bring Quinn right to you. He’s fairly talented, if the mage stone is any indication, and he, uh…”

“Might need a little help getting around,” I finished, looking down at my useless hands. Even at this distance, they were blurry and out of focus.

Lili looked up at me, questioningly, “The hands I can deal with, I know Apportation, I can manage. The trouble is, I’m just about half blind. Even at this distance, I can barely make out your facial features.”

“Did this also happen in Adympia?” Lili asked sympathetically.

*I’m already tired of explaining this.*

“Sort of. I caught the end of a spear with my face, which broke my glasses. They’re a sort of wire frame, with a pair of corrective glass lenses. With them I could see fine, at least when compared to other humans. Without out them, well. My vision sucks.”

“I might have something that can help,” she said, turning to rummage in the desk, though I didn’t get my hopes up.

“Here,” she said, holding out a necklace in the shape of a hawk feather, “It sounds like it won’t be quite as good as your glasses, but it should help a little.”

“Thank you,” I said, putting it on, “How does it work?” I asked, not seeing any difference.

“Just tap it,” She said, “Like this,” and she touched the little feather where it lay on my chest.

The sudden change was disorienting, and I nearly stumbled back into a table. My vision had narrowed right down, and while it was now flawless, better than flawless, my field of vision was maybe ten degrees across. Instead of wearing a pair of glasses, this was like looking through a telescope. I turned to look at Waenne, and this time the disorientation was enough for me to lose my balance. My ass hit the floor, and I had to close my eyes to avoid throwing up. I patted at my chest with numb hands, trying to turn the little necklace off. I must have looked rather foolish, but eventually the enchantment snapped off, so I must have found my mark.

I opened my eyes to see the once again blurry forms of Waenne and Lili standing over me with concern.

“Are you alright?” Lili asked.

“I’m fine,” I said, still feeling nauseas, “But I think that’s going to take some getting used to.”

*But at least magical vision correction is possible, even if fixing my eyes directly is not.*

Waenne helped me up, and I was reminded of just how strong elves were, despite their small size.

*If Nothus has the same sort of strength as an elf… Damn.*

“Quinn,” Lili asked, once Waenne and I were seated across from her at her desk, “How did you manage to avoid being discovered as a Mage? Unless…” She looked to Waenne, and he shook his head,

“No collar,” he said simply.

“Waenne helped me sort out the answer to that. They check to see if someone has mana, right?” She nodded, “Well I’ve got none.”

“Pardon me? None?” She asked, leaning forwards.

I spread my hands, “I thought at first that I had exactly one, since I could only ever cast spells at their lowest level of effect, but apparently I have none.”

“Hmmm,” she tapped her chin with one finger, “Well that definitely shows that you’ve got some talent, and you’ve got to be fairly clever too. Can you, uh,” She said, waving at the hand that bore the mage stone.

“Sure,” I said, and I could see that Waenne was already shielding his eyes.

The stone bloomed to life, and Lili pulled back. I’d been too busy giggling at Waenne to notice that she’d been staring right at it.

“Alright, Alright, that’s enough thank you,” She said, rubbing at her eyes.

I let the light go out, “I hope you’ve got good news for me?” I asked.

“Oh I think so,” she said, “I don’t think that even Nothus put on quite the same light show as you did just now.”

*Sweet.*

“Why don’t we go downstairs, it’s fairly quiet today, I think we shouldn’t have any trouble finding you a spot so we can get some tests done,” Lili said.

“Tests?” I asked.

“Oh, numbers, reading, that sort of thing, and we’ll get a better idea of just how much magical talent you’ve got.”

-----

The three of us made our way downstairs, though Waenne did not follow Lili and I to the classroom where they had the tests.

“I’ll meet up with you after,” he said, “I’m going to check in with some friends I haven’t seen in a while. They won’t let me in the classroom anyway while you’re writing your entrance exams.”

“Alrigh- Hold on, I thought they were tests. Now they’re exams?” I said, suddenly a little anxious.

“Don’t worry, you’ll do fine,” he said, and I could more hear the smile than see it.

-----

Lili and I were just in time for the next round of tests, unless they were exams, and I followed the small group of students into the room. It was very much like a classroom on Earth, there was a chalk board, plenty of desks, and what might have been posters with charts or diagrams along the walls. There were maybe sixty desks, though only about ten students, not including myself. Lili had said that most students had already either written their exams, unless they were tests, or wouldn’t be here until the last week of admittance. This meant that it was fairly quiet, both here in the classroom, and in the university in general. I’d asked her, rather anxiously, about what I might be tested on and she’d assured me that it was nothing complicated. Some reading comprehension, some mathematics, basic puzzle solving, with some logic questions. It reminded me of and IQ tests, or the sort of aptitude test that the military might have new recruits do.

I need not have worried. This test seemed like it was intended for the absolute lowest common denominator. This wasn’t a test for people that were three and a half years into a Computer Science degree, it was a test for medieval peasants, and the odd noble that had someone to tutor them. In fact, of the ten other students, seven of them had someone sitting on a stool next to them, reading the test out to them, and they were dictating their answers back so that they could be written down.

I was done in all of ten minutes.

I set the parchments aside, and raised a hand to indicate that I was done, and Lili came over.

“What’s wrong?” she asked, looking at the papers I’d pushed aside, and then back to me.

“Nothing, I’m done. Can we leave, or do I need to wait?”

She raised her eyebrows, “We can go,” she said, scooping up the papers. I especially enjoyed the dirty looks I got from the pair of what must have been nobles, or sons of nobles, as I left.

We went into the next room, where a pair of what I assumed to be teachers were chatting. One had the reddish brown skin and short stature of a gnome, and the other looked to be a city elf with his silver hair.

“Something wrong?” One asked, looking between myself and Lili.

“No,” Lili smiled, “Quinn here is all done. Could you check over his work Djeta while Sisaru helps me sort out just how talented Quinn is?”

The gnome, Djeta I guessed, shrugged, “Sure,” he said, in a surprisingly deep voice for such a small creature.

Lili handed over my test, and then indicated a chair that faced the city elf across a low table, “Please, take a seat.”

I sat while the elf, Sisaru, fished around in a bag for something. A moment later he dropped a truly massive crystal onto the table. The thing must have been as big as my head, and it was a deep purple. It was rough, but polished, and seemed to be all once piece.

“I take it that you have used a mage stone before?” Sisaru asked, and I nodded, “Well this is exactly the same. You focus on the stone, and through it I will be able to sort out just where you belong.”

From the looks of him, I’d have guessed that Sisaru wasn’t much older than myself. For an elf, that might still put him somewhere in his forties, but it was the voice that threw a wrench into that assumption. He spoke like someone that was very, very old. He didn’t speak slowly, but each word was deliberate, and had weight to it.

I did as bade, and put my hands on the stone.

“Whenever you are ready,” Sisaru said, in his ancient voice.

The crystal flared to life, though not nearly as brightly as my ring had. It was too bright to look directly into, but I didn’t need to avert my eyes.

“Hmm, very good,” Sisaru said after a moment, taking his hands away from the big crystal.

*Eighth level, eighth level, eighth level…*

“You’re at the sixth level,” he said.

*Damn.*

“Really?” Lili asked, “You should have seen the way that his ring lit up in my office.”

“Oh? Why don’t you show me Quinn?” He said.

I showed him, and the difference in brightness was clear to see.

“I’d guessed at least ninth level, what’s the reason for the difference?” Lili asked.

He seemed to consider the question before speaking, “There are a few causes that come to mind, though what is most likely is that Quinn here has a particularly strong Will. Strictly speaking, that is what the smaller stones are really testing after all. Speaking practically, you will be better able to resist magic used against you. It is not immunity mind you, but it does help a great deal.”

“Hmm, that does sound good,” I said, it was nice to have a little peace of mind.

“How would Quinn compare to Neferoy then?” Lili asked, leaning forwards and resting her chin in her hand.

“Oh, Neferoy would definitely have the advantage,” he said immediately, “Neferoy is not immune either, but she is as close as anyone can hope to be.”

“Neferoy?” I asked, looking between the two of them.

“One of my students, she’s a dwarf, and shares her race’s resistance to magic,” Lili explained, “Oh, you’ve marked it then?”

I turned to see Djeta walking over, parchments in hand, “Yes, I can’t make sense of the mess on the maths portion of the test, but the answers are correct. All of them, perfect score, well done.”

I grinned, “Thanks,” I said, “How many students usually get a perfect score?”

*Is it none?*

“Oh a few, sons and daughters of nobles and merchants usually, though you’re the first to finish so quickly,” he said.

*Aw, well I guess that’s good enough.*

Djeta laid out the test on the table, flipping to the math portion, “I was wondering about this,” he said, pointing to where I’d converted from pseudo-Roman numerals, *Elardian numerals?* to Arabic numerals to finish the questions more quickly.

-----

Lili had to drag Djeta away about twenty minutes later, when some of the other students started to come in to have their own tests marked. Djeta had taken to the new numbering system like a fish to water, and I’d barely noticed the time go by as I explained the system and answered his eager questions. He seemed willing to make the uppity pair of nobles wait, and it was only after some prodding from Lili that he got up to see to them. He made me promise, once we both had some free time, to come see him in his office to tell him more.

“Come on,” Lili said, “Sisaru has got to check over our new arrivals, and we might as well go by the bursar to get you your own money. We’ll also need get you a room until we find a club to put you in.”

“Club?”

“A group of people that meet to talk about shared interests, you don’t have clubs where you come from?” She teased, and I gave her a look. She grinned, wide enough for me to notice despite the poor quality of my vision, “Clubs are little groups of ten or twelve. So instead of having on professor for a lecture hall of a few hundred students, which is what we do for the less talented Mages, we’ve got one instructor for each club. Everyone learns a little differently, especially when you consider the differences in magical ability between those with lots of talent, and those with little, so this lets us tailor the instruction to each student.”

“I’m guessing that the pace of instruction is quite a bit faster?” I asked.

“Well, it depends. If you’re in the lecture stream then it’s a little more regimented, there are specific classes to take, though you can choose your area of focus,” she said, *sounds like an undergraduate program,* “But if you’re in the club stream then you’ve got a lot more independence. It will be up to you to decide just what it is you’re trying to accomplish, and your instructor will be there to help you along.”

*Sounds like a graduate or doctoral program.*

“There are classes to take, but those are a lot smaller as well. Depending on the popularity of the subject, and the teacher, you might only have twenty or so classmates.”

“Sounds like I’m going to enjoy my time here,” I said, smiling a little.

*Right, Time.*

“Quick question though, how long does a student usually spend learning here?” I asked.

“Well, it depends on the Mage, but some people stay almost indefinitely,” she said.

“Indefinitely?”

“It means-“ And I elbowed her lightly, she giggled, “There’s always more magic to learn Quinn. I switched from student to professor some time ago, but even I still take time out to learn more. Teaching is often one of the best ways to learn more about a subject. Mmm, especially if you join one of the guilds. Most guild Mages do stay indefinitely.”

“Oh? I think Waenne mentioned something about a guild, The Order of the Claves? What are they anyway?”

She laughed, “Right, the thing with the Font of Endless Custard, I remember that. I think they flooded two or three streets in the lower city. The Order of the Claves are one of the twelve, well, eleven, major guilds. The major guilds are basically an organization of the students, and a couple of the teachers, from the university. The hierarch of each guild is a bit above a Count in rank, and a bit below a Duke.”

“Really, do they control any land, or is their rank a result of the number of mages that they have answering to them?”

*If I was a medieval Count I wouldn’t want to screw with a guy that might have a twelfth of the university’s Mages at his command.*

“A little of both. A decent portion of Nimre’s land is controlled by the university, I think it’s nearly half. That area is split between the guilds. The guilds answer to the university itself, and the university answers to the Emperor.”

“So Nimre is a magocracy then? Or at least, part of it is?” I asked, the thought of a bunch of college students ruling anything seemed like a terrible idea.

*And it explains why the rest of Nimre is a little resentful.*

“Yes, part of it. A big part, but only a part. The rest is organized much like any of the other empires, do you…”

“Oh, yeah I’m familiar with the general idea, though I’m guessing that there’s some Elardia specific concepts that I’ll need to pick up along the way,” I reassured.

“I’m impressed Quinn. Very few of the students that arrive here are quite as educated as you seem to be, even Minki, and her father is an Archduke.”

*Does Crusader Kings 2 count as an education?*

I smiled, “I think I’ve probably got an unfair advantage there. I’ve been in school at least thirty hours a week, eight months out of twelve, since I was five years old. I don’t think anyone here in Elardia is crazy enough for that sort of schedule.”

She looked up at me, surprise evident on her face, “Since you were five, how old are you?”

“Well,” I paused, *How long have I been here? Has my birthday passed already?* “I’m twenty three.”

“That is quite the pace of study, and that’s normal for Humans?” She asked.

“Yeah, some people stop around eighteen if they’re not planning on continuing to university or college though.”

“I’ll have to ask Brandy what her education was like then, you said you were twenty three, you seem surprisingly mature for someone so young,” she said.

*Brandy? There’s no way in hell that any elf is named Brandy.*

“Well, that’s the thing,” I said, Brandy would have to wait, “Humans don’t live quite as long as elves do. With good healthcare, which hopefully magic can provide, I can expect to live to eighty or ninety. Though ninety would be pushing the limit. One hundred is possible, but unlikely.”

She stopped dead, and I turned to look back at her, “That’s not fair,” she said, seeming offended rather than sad or worried.

I smiled, but it was bittersweet, “I think you’re the second person to tell me that. I’ve heard life extension magic mentioned, is that possible? Would it work for a human?”

She strode up to me, and took my arm, “Yes. Yes it does. We’re going to the bursar, and then we’re getting this sorted out.”

She hurried me along, which was an impressive feat considering how much shorter her stride was.

-----

We didn’t need to wait long for the bursar, there was only one other person there to see him, and I leaned on the counter while I let Lili do the talking.

“Lili,” said the man behind the desk, not rudely, though he did seem thoroughly uninterested.

“Abil,” she acknowledged.

I’d expected a librarian looking sort, with wire rimmed spectacles and a scrunched up face, but then elves don’t need glasses, and they seem to age much more gracefully than humans do.

“His level of talent?” he asked.

“Six.”

He handed me a broach with some sort of seal on it, *the university’s seal?*

“One thousand, nine hundred, and twenty drachm. Don’t spend it all in one place,” he said, in a way that made it sound like this was the thousandth time he’d made that ‘joke’.

*One thousand and what?*

“Pardon me? Is that what this thing is worth?” I asked, turning the thing over in my hands. It did seem to be made of solid silver, and it was fairly large, about the size of a loonie, but nineteen hundred drachm seemed like a stretch.

“No,” Lili said, “This just lets you access your account here at the university. If you want to take some physical coins out then you can, but this will work anywhere in the city, and in most of the larger cities throughout Nimre.”

*Magical debit card, sweet.*

“Works for me, and this is what, this year’s bursary?” I asked.

*Five and a bit drachm a day, so roughly two and a half times the income of your average labourer? Not too bad.*

“If only,” said Abil, in his bored voice.

Lili smiled, “No, this is the bursary for this month.”

I blinked. *DAMN.*

“Well, thank you very much Abil,” I said sincerely, I could see why he had his reservations.

*I’ve never been to a university that* ***pays*** *you to learn there, but I think I like it.*

He waved a hand, “You’re welcome, though I’m not the one paying you.”

“Thanks all the same, I do have one question though. Who would I see about the bounty on these?” I asked, taking the two gold cuffs out of my pocket, and setting them on the counter between us.

Lili’s eyes got even bigger than usual, and Abil sighed heavily.

“That’s me as well. I’ll move another hundred thousand drachm to your account,” he said, as if the colossal sum of money was no more valuable than a sack of grain that he was moving from one cupboard to another.

It took me a minute to pick my jaw up off the floor, and I think my eyes might have turned into dollar signs.

*Damn, and now I’ve got to give half to Waenne.*

I really didn’t want to, and if I’d been smarter I would have set a specific value, but he’d held up his end of the deal so I wasn’t about to back out.

“I owe half of it to Waenne,” I said, “Can you transfer half to him? Does he even still have one of these broach thingies?”

“It’s your mark as a student, it is not a ‘thingy’” Abil said sternly, “But yes, I can transfer half to Waenne.”

“How’d you end up with that deal?” Lili asked wryly, as we left Abil to his own devices.

“I promised him half if he could get me here. I had some idea of what it was worth, but not precisely. Its fine I guess, I got what I wanted after all, I’m here.”

-----

As it turns out, you can have immortality, and it only costs a hundred drachm. At least, as long as you’re a Mage.

Well, it wasn’t quite immortality, and it wasn’t quite one hundred drachm. Lili had shown me to what was apparently the magical version of a hospital, and I allowed a small plump lady to place an enchantment on me. It would freeze my aging process for a single year. After that year was up I’d start to age as normal.

I of course, cried foul almost immediately.

“How in the hell can magic grant immortality, but not fix my hands or eyes?” I asked, a little exasperated.

“Immortality is simple,” said the plump woman, Nidab was her name, “Eyes are complicated, and so is fixing your hands.”

“Immortality is simple. Really. And it’s simpler than an eye?”

“All I need to do to make you immortal is make sure that you **don’t** change. Fixing your eye, well,” she waved her hands in my general direction, “I wouldn’t even know where to begin. I could give you someone else’s eyes, but they’d be too big, and even if they weren’t too big they still probably wouldn’t work.”

“Fine,” I said, throwing up my hands, “And this will last a year? Why only a year, what do I do after that?”

“Well you could get me to redo the enchantment,” Nidab said, “But it’s more likely that you’ll have learned to do it yourself by then. Immortality isn’t that hard after all. And it only lasts a year, because that’s how long the enchantment can hold together.”

“What does the enchantment do exactly?”

“Lili?” Nidab asked, “You’re better at explaining this sort of thing.”

“Sure,” Lili said, “The enchantment takes advantage of the fact that you’re able to channel mana naturally, even if you have none of your own, and uses the ambient mana to power the spell. And like Nidab said, the spell just freezes your age where it is now. It only takes a little mana, and there’s always plenty around. You’ll learn to do that unconsciously eventually, and then you won’t need someone to set up an enchantment to do it for you anymore.”

“What if I wasn’t a Mage?” I asked.

“Well then I’d need to provide all the mana upfront, which would make it much more expensive. I’d need quite a bit of help, or a big sack of mana stones,” Nidab said.

“And immortality is simple,” I said wryly, looking at Nidab.

“Yes.”

“I still say that makes no sense. Thank you though.”

“You’re welcome.”

-----

It was getting a little late, and I could see the sun nearing the horizon. Waenne had come and gone, thanking me profusely for the substantial payment, promising that it would be put to good use. Then he was on his way in a hurry, I imagine that he didn’t want Cilla to get any ideas. Lili took me to dinner, or tried to. She tried to pay, but I insisted. I’d just been handed a not so small fortune after all, and she asked the questions that Waenne had said she would ask. I gave her the same answer that I’d given Waenne, and she seemed satisfied.

Lili led me to a rather nice inn, one where she seemed to know the owner, and a room was found for me that would accommodate my size. I set down my pack, and it reminded me of just how little I had. An oilskin tarp, a silk hammock, one pen, a multitool, a folding knife, my watch, two rings, a waterproof jacket, one pair of dark blue jeans, one dark blue shirt which was roughly mended, one pair of black socks, one pair underwear, and one pair of Gore-Tex shoes. I’d left the Adympian clothes in Waenne’s house, he could burn them for all I cared. It was a strange juxtaposition. The possessions looked like they belonged to the world’s most strangely prepared tramp, but they sat in the corner of a positively palatial room. It was every bit as nice as the bedroom I’d shared with Chypia.

“I’ll need to go clothes shopping tomorrow,” I said softly, looking over my things.

“Don’t worry,” Lili said, “I should be able to help you get acquainted. I’ll show you around to some of the clubs as well. I think that there’s a few that aren’t quite full yet, we’ll find a place for you.”

*That reminds me…*

“You mentioned someone named Brandy? Are there other humans here in Nimre?” I asked.

There was a knock on the door, just as she was about to answer, and I went to see who it was. It was a servant, bearing a tray with a teapot and two cups. I hadn’t ordered any tea, but I let her into the room. She set the tray on the coffee table, *tea table?* and poured steaming tea for both of us before bowing and leaving. I took a seat in an armchair, and Lili sprawled across a small sofa. Well, elf sized sofa. I was never really a tea person, but I sipped at it politely as Lili spoke, teacup dangling negligently from one hand.

“Brandy, she’s one of my students. She’s human, and I think there’s a family of humans that have caught the attention of King Nezzabi,” she explained.

“Caught the attention? In a bad way or a good way?” I asked.

“In a good way. I’m not sure just what he has them doing for him, but he seems to be thinking about handing off one of his duchies to be managed by them. Something about ‘Earth’ having more advanced technology.”

“Yeah, makes sense,” I said, “If I hadn’t discovered that I had magic then I’d probably have gone looking for some noble to share some Earth technology with.”

“And now?” She asked, “What are you planning to do with your human secrets?”

“Well,” I laughed, “I’m apparently teaching math to Djeta. Beyond that, I’m not sure. I imagine that this family you mentioned is going to try for most of the obvious stuff, gunpowder, penicillin, pasteurization of milk, germ theory, inoculation, maybe even vaccination, though that one is harder. I’ll probably end up making something silly like a magic typewriter.”

“Gunpowder?” she asked, interested.

Lili picked my brain for a couple of hours, asking about each of the things I’d mentioned, and I did my best to explain. Germ theory was apparently understood to some extent, at least within the university, though the rest seemed entirely new to her. She stayed quite late, late enough that I was a little unsure of just where this was going. I got the feeling that something was expected of me, but I had no idea what that might be, or even how to approach the situation in general. I wasn’t even sure I wanted a part in what Lili seemed to be waiting for. I always felt awkward in situations like this, and the fact that I really hadn’t gotten over my time in Chypia’s hands didn’t make things any easier for me.

Thankfully Lili seemed to get the idea after a while, and she let me know that she’d be here at nine tomorrow to keep showing me around. She left, and I sat and appreciated the silence.

*When was the last time I was able to sleep alone, in a proper bed, in a quiet room?*

I considered this, as I lay in a steaming hot bath. Not in Adympia, either Chypia had been in bed with me, or Aris had been laying in that silly little drawer. Not on the ship, that had been a hammock, and there were always at least a few people clomping around in the hall. Not in Myra, I slept with Thera every night, not that I’d minded too much. Not on the road, that was the hammock again, and Sila and the rest had been along with me. Harp’s snoring hadn’t helped. That left the valley, and while that had been a bed, it was not a ‘proper’ one. It had been quiet thankfully, and I’d been alone, but the bed was about a foot too short and the sheets were not anything like what I’d been used to sleeping on.

No, the last time I’d slept in a bed this nice, with no one to bother me, had been back home. *No, not back home, back on Earth.* The university was home now, and if someone had offered me the chance to go home, to replace my glasses, maybe even start the treatment that would have repaired the nerve damage to my hands…

If they’d offered that, I would have run screaming in the other direction.

*I’m here, to hell with everything else.*


# Chapter 25

Quinn

-----

I woke up the following morning feeling amazing. My hands were still useless, and my vision was still a mess, but I had true freedom for the first time in ages. It wasn’t as simple as not being a slave any more, though that definitely helped, true freedom came from the resources that I now had. Fifty two thousand drachm in the bank, with nearly two thousand more every month. The rich might spend money on a different scale than the average labourer, but 71 years’ worth of labourer’s wages had to count for something. On top of that, immortality was apparently less than a year away. For the first time in ages I could truly do as I pleased.

I got up early, which was a small miracle, and by the time Lili arrived I had already washed, shaved, and eaten.

The first order of business for the day would be to get some new clothes, and a school uniform. I liked the idea of new clothes, I liked the idea of a school uniform less.

“When exactly am I required to wear the uniform?” I asked, as we walked through the campus.

“Whenever you’re attending classes, though more of your instruction will be less formal since you’ve placed into the club stream, so you won’t actually be ‘in class’ quite as often as some of the less talented students. It’s not a ‘uniform’ though Quinn. They’re your school robes, and most students are **pleased** to finally be able to wear the robes of the university,” she said, a little reproachfully.

“They’re not a uniform, but they all share the same styling and the same colours, and they mark me as a member of the university. Sounds a lot like a uniform to me,” I said.

“It’s not all the same colours Quinn,” she assured me, “You have plenty of choice when it comes to colour, and maybe a little choice in the style. You must have noticed that not everyone was dressed exactly the same. I’m wearing my own university robes after all, and not everyone is wearing the exact same shade of blue as myself.”

I frowned, “Then… That doesn’t make any sense. How would anyone be able to tell a university mage from any other mage? If there’s so much choice then couldn’t I just declare to be the clothes I’m wearing now to be my mage robes?”

“Just let me get this straight,” she said, giving me a wry look, “First you balk at the thought of wearing a ‘uniform’ that many people less talented than you would give their left arm to be able to wear, and then you cry foul when I tell you that you have plenty of choice in just what sort of ‘uniform’ you wear?”

“Well, it just seems rather disorganized,” I said lamely, “What kind of military would tell their soldiers that they all need to wear this specific uniform, except they can each decide for themselves what colour that uniform is, and just how it looks. That’s no uniform at all.”

“It’s not a uniform at all Quinn!” She said, laughing.

“Fine,” I said, throwing up my hands, “How much choice do I have then, and what constraints do I need to abide by?”

“If there’s any at all,” I grumbled.

“Oh stop it you, there’s plenty of constraints. When it comes to colour you’ll have plenty of choice, though there will be a few that are off limits. Style you’ll have a lot less choice, for you it mostly comes down to just how much trim you want, and what colour you want it to be,” she explained.

“Why would some colours be off limits?” I asked.

“Purple, Indigo, Gold, Crimson, and Orange,” she listed, counting off on fingers, “They’re reserved for those with titles, or the relatives of those with titles. You’ll likely not be able to get robes in as dark a blue as your current attire for example. The trim is much the same, there are the same restrictions on colour, it’s more a matter of the amount of trim and other decorations that’s allowed on your robes.”

*So what, only royalty gets purple? I wonder if I’m descended from royalty… Well, go back far enough…*

“And my claim to those colours is not granted, purely based on the fact that I was the victim of a Banestorm?” I asked, putting just the hint of indignance into my words.

This seemed to give her pause, and she looked up at me, a little surprised, “You are from a noble family?”

“Of course, and depending on how the university’s sumptuary laws I might have the right to wear any or all of those colours,” I said.

*Sumptuary, see? I even know the right fancy words.*

“Well,” she said, considering this new information, “Only relatives of an imperial family may wear purple. Indigo is reserved for royal families, and gold for ducal families. Crimson for counts and their relatives, and orange for the families of barons. Of course, someone of higher rank may wear the colours of the ranks below, though they tend not to. We’ll need to have a bill of pedigree notarized for you though, we’ll do that first.”

“Of course,” I acknowledged, as if it only made sense.

*Bill of pedigree? I think that’s an item in D&D? Or is that a scroll of pedigree… Either way, it’s not like they can check my story.*

-----

“And the dynasty in question that you claim significant relation to?” Asked the notary, who had just lit an enchanted candle that would compel me to tell the truth.

*I kinda should have seen this coming.*

“The Carolingian dynasty”, I said.

“And you assert that the, uh, Carolingian dynasty, is an imperial dynasty?” He asked.

“Yes,” I said.

“And their claim to empire is on what grounds? The Carolingian empire consists of which kingdoms?”

*Consists of, not consisted of, damn. To hell with it, let’s see what happens.*

“The kingdoms in question would be West, Middle, and Eastern Francia, along with Lombardy,” I said, *I think I’m still okay here.*

It might have been a good thing that they were relying on magic for this, especially since it was **compelling** truth, rather than detecting falsehoods. I definitely felt some… weight, on my mind as I spoke. And I found myself changing the odd word just before speaking, but rather than catch me out as a liar, it was helping me along.

*If they were using a polygraph I’d be screwed, I can hear my freaking heartbeat right now.*

“Well this seems to be in order,” he said, he seemed as surprised as I was that I was getting away with this, ”Could you please describe your family’s coat of arms to the herald?”

*I’m really glad I Googled ‘Angove’ that one time.*

“Sure,” I said, as a young elf set a sketch pad on the table between myself and the notary, “A black eagle on a silver field, with a cross of black diamonds behind it. The mantling is black and maroon, and the helmet wears a gold crown.”

I watched as the young elf, some sort of apprentice I guessed, sketched out the Angove coat of arms. The helmet ended up looking a little flimsier than I remembered it being, and I had to correct him on the colour since it was steel rather than bronze, but he finished and I got my little piece of paper that told everyone what I was worth.

*Do I get to wear double-purple if I tell them about Emperor Caesar, Genghis Khan, and every other ‘imperial’ family that I can draw a probable link to?*

-----

Our next stop was a tailor, and while it didn’t have a fancy name like an English tailor might have, this was apparently the place where the well-to-do families would go to have bespoke robes made. It certainly felt a lot like an English tailor, or at least it looked a lot like the tailor from the Kingsman movie.

Lili was sitting in a chair, giggling like a little schoolgirl, as the proprietor, who was a gnome, tried to measure me. He was not having a lot of success.

He did his best to maintain an air of dignity as he dragged over a stepladder.

The small gnome summited the stepladder, taking his measurements, before beginning the perilous decent back to earth.

“This is certainly going to be the largest article I’ve ever worked on,” he said, bending over backwards to look up at me.

He had spoken formally throughout our conversation, though he wasn’t cold, and neither was he quite as stuffy as Abil had been. He was professional, he catered to the sort of clientele that expected that after all, but he seemed to genuinely enjoy his work. Unlike the few other gnomes I’d met so far Khory wasn’t the same reddish brown that reminded me of Prince Edward Island. Instead he was the same sort of dark brown, almost black, of fresh topsoil, though he had the same close cut hair and goatee of the other gnomes.

I shrugged, “There’s not a whole lot I can do about that,” I said, “Hopefully it won’t take too long?”

“Not too much longer, you need this quickly?” He asked.

“Oh I just need it in time for classes,” I said, “I assume I don’t need them sooner,” I asked, turning to look at Lili, who had finally gotten herself under control.

“You’ll be fine with normal clothes until then,” she said, nodding.

“Well there we are, have you got any samples I can look at for cut and colour then?” I asked, turning back to Khory.

“Certainly, just give me a moment and I’ll bring out some pieces that you might like the look of. Itys, would you see to our guests in the meantime please?”

Kory’s assistant, and the first female gnome I’d ever met, asked politely if we wanted any refreshments and Lili accepted a cup of tea while I settled for water and mourned the loss of my hot chocolate packets. Those had been destroyed the first time I’d taken an accidental swim.

“What is it that you don’t like uniforms about Quinn?” Lili asked, once the assistant retreated.

“Uniforms themselves are fine, I’ve got nothing against them. I just don’t like it when I’m expected to wear them. I don’t like the idea of anyone else deciding things for me.”

“Even something as simple as the clothes you wear?” She asked.

“Clothes are one of the most important things, exactly because they’re so simple. Even if you’re not wearing a uniform, your clothes still say a lot about you, they define you for the rest of the world. And if you’re wearing a uniform, then you’re defining yourself by your membership in the organization that the uniform belongs to.”

“But don’t you want to be a Mage? It seems to me like you half killed yourself to get here,” she said, leaning towards me and resting her chin in her hand.

“I do, I just don’t need the uniform to define me. Maybe I’m just being overly sensitive about it, but I’ve never liked it when anything or anyone gets to make my decisions for me. The society I’m from is very individualistic, maybe the most individualistic society that’s ever existed on my world, and even there, I’m probably an extreme case.”

“Extreme how Quinn?”

“Well, there’d always be extra curricular activities that I could sign up for at school for example. Sports, gaming clubs, that sort of thing. I never did like sports, but some of the gaming clubs always seemed interesting. So I’d try joining one. It would always go the same, I’d show up, have fun, meet people that shared my interests, and then after the second or third time I’d just stop going. Not because I wasn’t enjoying myself, but because I always hated that being part of the club meant that some time was not my own. Some time every week, or every two weeks, belonged to that club. It sounds foolish, I know, but it’s just the way I am.”

“I think I understand, somewhat,” she said, nodding.

“Thank you.”

“It’s not a uniform though.”

I threw up my hands in surrender, “Fine,” I said, laughing.

Khory came back and laid out several robes. All were far too small for me, but were a fairly good example of Khory’s craftsmanship. Khory waited patiently, giving me time to consider what he’d laid out. When Lili had said that higher ranking nobles were allowed more variety when it came to trim, it seemed that what she had really meant was that they were allowed a significantly higher amount of gaudiness. One set of purple robes had gold trim about as thick around as my wrist. It was far beyond ‘trim’, this looked more like someone had wrapped a gold fishing net around a purple silk poncho.

“I like how this one is cut,” I said, patting a slightly less ostentatious example of Khory’s work, ”Though the trim is still a little excessive for my tastes.”

I walked to one wall, where the robes that one might by ‘off-the-rack’ hung, “What I’d like is trim more like what’s on this one,” I said, pointing out one robe in particular.

“That one?” he asked, surprised, “That’s not very much at all.”

“Exactly, that’s exactly what I want. I prefer to go for understatement, rather than something as flashy as this,” I said, pointing back to purple and gold robes.

He nodded, considering, “I can certainly do that, would you still prefer gold, or did you have a different colour in mind?”

“Purple, as dark as you can make it, with the rest being indigo.”

“Pardon me, the trim will be purple, and the rest will be indigo?” He asked, looking between myself and Lili.

“Generally Quinn,” Lili started, “The ranking colour would be the more dominant one, to better show rank. Trim is usually reserved for a family colour, or a colour that the wearer particularly likes, if it’s not simply gold.”

*’Simply gold’*

“Yeah, but I like blue. I mean, look at what I’m wearing,” I said, waving a hand across my front, “The only thing not blue are my socks, and they’re black.”

“You’re just poking fun at the university’s rules for student attire, aren't you Quinn?” Lili asked.

“Maybe,” I said, grinning, “Hold on, there are specific rules then? Is there a big book somewhere where they’re all written down?”

“Yes, I have a copy of the university’s dress code,” Khory said, “Though it’s not quite that large, would you like to see it?”

“Yes please,”

“Itys?” Khory called.

“Yessir,” she replied, and I could hear her pulling open drawers and riffling around.

“You’re just looking for some rule to abuse, aren't you?” Lili asked me, and while she was sitting too far away for me to tell, she had to be giving me an exasperated look.

I just smiled, and took the small pamphlet from Itys when she brought it out.

There was some promising stuff here, though nothing really jumped out as being munchkinable. That was, until I got to the section on minimum length. It was defined in absolute, rather than relative terms.

“Alright, new plan Khor. I think I know exactly what I want,” I said, smile spreading.

Lili just leaned back, running both hands through her hair.

“That is always good to hear, what do you have in mind?” He asked.

“So the main colour is still indigo, and the trim still dark purple, but the cut will be rather different. Instead of falling to mid-calf or lower, it’s going to come down only as far as here,” I said, indicating my upper thigh area, “Only two pockets, and they’re be right about here,” I patted my stomach area, “And the trim will be two thin lines, just along the edges here,” I drew a line down the centre of my chest, “Oh, and it will need a hood.”

I was getting odd looks from both of them, though Khory’s was professionally odd.

“That’s not really a robe Quinn,” Lili said.

“I’m afraid I must agree with the professor,” Khory concurred.

“Maybe, but it’s within the dress code,” I said, “They say a robe needs to be at least this long, it’s at least this long. I’m only doing what I’m told.”

Lili sighed, leaning over the back of the chair, arms splayed out to either side, “I’m just glad that you’re not going to be **my** student.”

“It is rather clever though,” Khory said appreciatively, “This isn’t a look that anyone else will be able to achieve.”

“Thank you Khory, I’m glad that someone appreciates my genius.”

Khory and I took a little time to flesh out the details, and he sketched out a design for my final approval. I ordered five such sets of ‘robes’, with a two more full length sets for good measure.

*A silk hoodie. My school uniform is apparently now a silk hoodie. I’ve done something either very right, or very wrong.*

-----

“What’s next? Is there somewhere I can get normal clothes?” I asked, as we left Khory’s shop.

“No, we’ll need to find you a club first. You’ll need somewhere to put your things after all,” she explained.

“Wait, would I be living with these people?”

I was struck suddenly by the thought of living in what amounted to a magical frat house. I imagined a large townhouse, smelling faintly of beer and urine, and populated by bro-dudes with what amounted to superpowers. I never joined a frat when I was at U of T, I never felt the need for it. I know that for many people ‘Greek Life’ was an indispensable part of going to college, camaraderie, brotherhood, etcetera, etcetera, but that never really appealed to me. To me a frat meant partying, hazing, and the consumption of large volumes of alcohol. Crippling social anxiety meant that parties were more a burden than anything, hazing just reminded me of the less pleasant years of my time at school, and I very rarely drink.

*Don’t be so harsh Quinn, everyone here is either a Mage or a Wizard, that means that they’ll all be quiet bookish types like me, right?*

“It’s not a requirement Quinn, but most of the time the members of a club will all pitch in to rent or lease a floor in one of the buildings on campus. Why are you so reluctant Quinn? ” She asked, and I could just hear the edge of irritation creeping into her voice.

“I’m sorry Lili, I might be a little prejudiced. It’s not that I’m ungrateful, or that I hate how the university does things. You show me around, and I promise to shut up until I’ve actually got something to complain about.”

“Fine,” she said with a small smile, “But I’m going to hold you to that.”

-----

As it turned out, everyone at the university was not a quiet bookish type like myself.

According to Lili there were a grand total of thirty five clubs at the university, and we’d been through eight already.

“Now, why don’t you tell me what was wrong with those clubs?” She asked, as we left the square stone building that the Cro-Magnon inhabitants had called the ‘Cock Block’.

“Why do you think I had a problem with any of them?” I asked, a little defensively.

She gave me a pointed look, “Each time we stepped into one of the club’s apartments you got about as tense as a hunted animal, and you didn’t relax until after we’d finally left.”

It wasn’t that the people she’d introduced me to weren’t nice people, calling them all ‘magical bro-dudes’ was certainly too harsh. They were all polite and perfectly friendly as they introduced themselves, but they just weren’t the sort of people that I usually picked as friends. If they were back home they’d be the ‘trendy’ people. Though that didn’t mean that they were all assholes, often the opposite was true, and to say I was afraid of them was also incorrect. The tension came instead from the effort it took to appear ‘normal’, and it did take an effort. The parts of life that came naturally to most people were foreign to me. While most people would pick up on social cues immediately, or always know what the next thing to say was, I had no such natural instinct. That’s not to say that I couldn’t manage, I wasn’t a total head case, I could hold a conversation, even come off as charming, but I had to think about each and every word I was about to say before I spoke. I had to check and double check that I wasn’t about to put my foot in my mouth, and I had to take time to consider each and every person in the room. I’d look at their posture, their facial expressions, though that was harder now that my glasses were gone, and then take time to sort out just what their expression and stance meant. This was something that most people could do naturally, for me though, this had been something that I’d needed to learn, and even then I still made mistakes. I could manage this immense mental calculus when I was only talking to one other person without too much difficulty, even two wasn’t too hard, but in a large group I could barely keep track. It was easier once I got to know the group in question, but even then it could be hard to keep track of myself. I didn’t want to need to spend every waking hour ‘acting’ though, I much preferred a group, or a ‘club’ as Lili called it, that would take me as I am.

I sighed, “It’s not that I don’t appreciate your help Lili-“

“Quinn, I’m not offended, I genuinely want to know what’s bothering you. I don’t want to put you some place that will make you tense and unhappy, you might spend years with the people in your group. But you’ve got to help me help you. I’ve already been through nearly all of the top ten clubs, and you had the same frightened animal look when I was introducing you to each of them, even if you might have kept it hidden from the other students.”

“Top ten?” I asked, “Really?”

“Yes Quinn,” she said, laughing, “You’re smart, and very talented. You belong with the best, you’re just making it really difficult for me to **put** you with the best,” she said, grabbing me by the arm and shaking me, though she hadn’t quite stopped laughing.

“Well, maybe I’ve been too hasty, but there’s got to be more people like me in the top ten clubs. I mean, it’s only sensible.”

“Only sensible?” She asked wryly, “What do you mean, people like you?”

Now it was my turn to laugh, “Quiet, bookish types, that when they’re introduced to new people act like frightened animals. Not to be too arrogant, but someone who sits down and reads for fun has got to have better luck when it comes to magic, given equal talent. Just spending more time studying has got to count for something. Are you telling me that there are no other people like that in the whole university?”

She wrinkled her brow, “Of course there’s people like that Quinn, they’re just not all packed into one group. **They’re** usually happy to be put into any club at all, and put up with the fact that their club mates might be a little rowdy.”

“I get it, but you said that there’s thirty five of these groups. We’ve been through less than a quarter, aren’t there some that would be a little more… booky?”

“Actually we’ve been through half of the clubs, the other eighteen clubs are all specifically for women,” she explained.

“The clubs are segregated by gender? I suppose I didn’t notice any women in the clubs you’ve shown me so far,” I considered.

“It’s not a hard and fast rule, but the women led clubs don’t invite men to join. It’s hard enough to get a spot here if you’re a man, imagine how much harder it is for a woman.”

“And I bet that the male students, especially the noble ones, aren’t fans of having a woman boss them around,” I said, understanding.

“Exactly, so when a woman gets the chance to lead a club, she really only has other women to pick from. And, when a woman is looking for a club she tends not to pick one where she’ll end up placing herself under the power of a man. There were some… incidents, involving certain sons of nobles and merchants, and certain daughters of lesser nobles, or daughters of peasant families.”

“Basically some prick on a power trip decided to entertain himself with people that couldn’t properly defend themselves,” I said darkly.

*Sounds a lot like every sexual assault scandal I’ve ever heard about in the news. Giant asshole with power takes advantage of the women under him.*

“Yes,” she grimaced.

“What if…” I started, considering an idea, “What if it was the other way around?”

“What do you mean, the other way around?” She asked, giving me the side eye.

“I don’t have a problem with a woman as club leader. As long as I wouldn’t be committing some incredible faux pas, or being improper, could you find a group for me among the female half of the clubs?”

Her shoulders slumped, “Shit,” she said, under her breath.

“Uh…” This was the first time I’d heard her swear.

She straightened, and stepped infront of me, pointing a finger at my chest, “I’m going to take you to meet Victorina. You’re going to wait outside while I tell her about you. If she doesn’t like the sound of you, we leave, you don’t even walk in the door. If you meet her, and she still doesn’t like you, we leave immediately. If she talks to her club mates and they don’t like you, you also leave. And if you don’t like those rules then you can go looking for a club yourself, understand?”

I nodded, “Fair enough.”

-----


# Chapter 26

Quinn

-----

“Alright, get in here,” Lili said, poking her head outside.

Victorina’s clubhouse was a fairly impressive building, nearly as large as the ‘Cock Block’ had been, and that building had been split between five different clubs. This building on the other hand was entirely the domain of Victorina’s club. While the Cock Block had been a large, grey, boxy structure, this building was more like a small manor. It was only three stories, compared to the other building’s five, but it was more spread out. It wasn’t huge, clubs apparently had an upper limit of twelve people, and this place looked like it could just about manage one bedroom per person if Victorina decided to fill her club to capacity.

Lili lead me inside, up the large sweeping stairs in the centre of the foyer, and along the balcony that overhung the first floor.  

“Just in here,” Lili said, pushing open a door that lead into a large kitchen.

It was fairly well appointed, and while it definitely had a medieval feeling, it was laid out much like a modern kitchen on earth. If I didn’t know better I’d say that the oven was electric, and one of the cabinets against one wall looked an awful lot like a fridge.

*Magic oven? Magic fridge?*

Leaning on a large kitchen island was a very generously proportioned elf. She had wide hips and broad shoulders, with a very ample bosom. Her purple robes were drawn in at the back to emphasize a rather narrow waist, and the dress was cut a little low in the front. Compared to Earth clothing it was still rather tame, but it was certainly provocative by the standards of Elardia. I couldn’t make out much of her facial features, even at this distance, but I found her hair was rather striking. It looked like fine steel wire, falling in waves down her back, it even had the metallic sheen of steel. It gave her a rather severe look, and it complemented the silver trim on her robes rather well.

*Purple, empressive.*

“Lili wasn’t exaggerating when she told me that you were a giant,” the steel haired woman said, extending a hand, “It’s nice to meet you, I’m Victorina.”

“I’m Quinn, uh, Lili?” I said, looking over at where she was leaning against the kitchen counter, before looking back to Victorina.

“I didn’t mention your hands Quinn, I thought that you’d rather do that yourself,” she explained.

*Damn.*

Victorina withdrew her hand, “Is there something the matter with your hands?” She asked, giving me the side eye.

I rested my elbows on the island between us, “Yeah, they don’t work. No feeling, and barely any movement.”

“That,” She started, “Sounds an awful lot like the damage done by Adympian slave manacles. Do you know a Mage by the name of Waenne? Most of the escaped slaves he helps have similar problems, he might know a spell that could help.”

“Well,” I said, wryly, “Funny thing…”

”Oh… I’m sorry.”

I just shrugged, “I can manage, I just cast Apportation a lot.”

“But… how could you have escaped? A Mage collar would have prevented you from even **thinking** too hard about escape.”

“They didn’t figure out that I was a Mage, so I just ended up as a steward. Still wasn’t much fun, so I escaped as soon as I could. I… I don’t really want to talk about it. I’m here now, and what’s over is over.”

“I understand,” she said quietly.

“I don’t mean to be rude, but do you?” I asked.

She was quiet for a moment, long enough that I thought she might not answer, but then she spoke, “Yeah. My father was, or is, Emperor Viuso.”

My eyes got really wide, and I blinked a lot as I considered what she’d just told me. *Emperor Viuso. Oh, he’s nobody important, just the Emperor of Adympia.*

We both stood there silently for a moment, leaning against the island, thinking our own private thoughts. I could see Lili edge backwards, just out of the corner of my eye, trying not to be intrusive.

“If you don’t mind me asking,” I started, “How did *you* escape, did someone manage to help y-“

“No!” She said, looking me in the eyes, and slapping a hand down on the table, “I didn’t have or need anyone’s help. I got out on my own.”

I raised my useless hands, “I’m sorry, I didn’t mean anything by it. I wasn’t in Adympia too long, but from what people have alluded to about the collars, especially what you just said, makes it sound like they’re pretty inescapable. At least if you don’t have help.”

*I wonder if Chypia has managed to free Concia yet?*

“I managed to escape before I was ever discovered to be a Mage, so I never had to deal with the collar,” she said, “Or the slave manacles,” she added, casting a glance at my hands.

“I’m still new to this whole magic thing, but isn’t magical ability determined at birth? Wouldn’t they have known what you were from the start?” I asked, keeping my voice soft.

“Yes, but you can’t get a reliable reading on a person until they hit puberty, at least the way the Adympians do it.”

“You mean how they check to see if you have mana?” I asked.

“Yeah, I’d already figured out what I was for myself, well before it came time for me to be checked for magical ability. So I left,” she said, lifting her face to meet my eyes.

“Hold on, you escaped Adympia when you were, what, twelve? And you had no help at all?” I asked, surprised, but also impressed as hell.

“Eleven. And yes, I did it all on my own.”

“Damn. Have you been here at the university since then?”

“Yeah, yeah I have. What about you, how did you escape?” she asked, for the second time now.

*Pretty sure she’s earned her answer.*

“I managed to get into my… captor’s, good graces. She gave me a little freedom to move about the city, to run errands for her, I was meant to be her steward after all-“

“She?” She asked, “Did she ever…” she started to say.

I just raised a hand, looking away for a moment.

*I don’t think I realized how much it got to me before, but now, putting it into words…*

“I assembled some things that I thought I might need on my way out of the country,” I continued, “and one night I slipped into the harbour, and swam around the sea wall. I’d bought myself a bit of a head start, and I managed to get far enough that by the time their search party had caught up with me I was already at the border. There was a little scuffle, but I managed to escape. Waenne found me the following day.”

“The following day- That’s why your hands are totally numb?” She asked, clearly surprised.

“Yeah, had them on nearly twenty four hours.”

“How did you manage to keep yourself going through all of that?” She asked.

“Honestly? No idea, I don’t remember most of it. I just woke up yesterday morning to find that Waenne had taken me in and gotten the cuffs off.”

“Wait, yesterday MORNING?” Victorina exclaimed, bolting up straight, slapping both hands on the island. She seemed almost angry for some reason.

“You’ve only been free for two days?” Lili shouted, also seeming angry with me.

I drew back from both of them, “Sorry?”

Lili calmed herself, “Quinn…” she sighed, putting her head in her hands, “And Waenne just let you out of bed? You should be resting!”

“Well, I kind of insisted. And I might have also bribed him.”

“You bribed someone to **not** take care of you?” Victorina asked, exasperated.

I shrugged, I was kind of lost here, “I wanted to get to the university.”

Victorina shook her head, laughing softly. She looked over at Lili, gesturing at me helplessly, “Is there anything else I need to know about?”

Lili looked up, and gave me a pointed look.

“Oh, right. I’m also half blind.”

“Are you serious?” Victorina asked, the humour in her voice lost.

I shrugged again, “My vision is very poor, even right now I can barely make out your facial features. And anything more than about a foot away starts to get more and more out of focus.”

“Is that normal for humans?”

“Kind of? Some humans don’t have very good vision, due to age, circumstances, or bad luck. I had glasses, they’re basically just lenses that would correct the flaws in my vision, but I lost them in the scuffle with the search party.”

Victorina looked towards Lili, “Is there anything you can do Lili?”

“I gave him a Hawk Vision amulet, I don’t really think it’s quite what he needs, but it’s the best I had to hand,” Lili said.

“I appreciate it Lili, it definitely helps. Really all I’d change would be to make the field of vision wider.”

“That shouldn’t be too hard to do,” said Victorina, frowning in thought and running a hand through her hair, “It will mean designing a new enchantment, but we’d have Hawk Vision to work from.”

“We? Does that mean…” I asked, a little hopefully.

“Yeah,” Victorina said softly, “I want to introduce you to the rest of the club before I promise anything, but I think you’ll fit in just fine. It’s not like you lack commitment, and that’s what we need if we’re going to compete with the other clubs.”

“You don’t have one of the guilds backing you up do you?” I asked.

“No, we don’t,” Victorina said, a little bitterly, “The university provides their own lab space, and we’ve got our own little library here, but it would be nice to have the resources that some of the other clubs have. I know that there’s a lab in the basement of the Cock Block that’s every bit as good as what the university makes available. And they don’t need to fight with every other student for access to it.”

*Maybe I can help out with that, it’s not like I don’t have the money.*

“Well, enough of that for now, let’s go see the rest of the team,” Victorina said, changing the subject.

-----

Victorina led Lili and I to a large sitting room at the back of the manor. It had large arched windows running along the back wall, and I could see a set of French doors that led to a balcony jutting out from the rear of the building. There were five women sitting, sprawled, and curled up on various armchairs and sofas that sat in the room, facing in towards a large coffee table.

“You’re just making fun of us Brandy, there’s no way that yoga pants are something human women really wear outside, I can see practically everything right now,” A plush, brass haired elf was saying, as she gestured at the legs of one of her friends.

He friend looked fairly human, long blonde hair, build on the same scale as Victorina, and she was wearing black yoga pants and a grey hoodie.

“They’re called yoga pants Ken, yoga pants. And they are super-duper comfy.”

The one that Brandy had called Ken seemed to notice me, and started waving her fingers in my direction, “Brandy!” she said, hunching down a little.

Brandy looked over at me, flicking her hair over her shoulder, “What? Oh, hi there,” she said brightly.

She hopped up, rather excitedly, and grabbed hold of my, hand shaking it, “It is super great to meet another human, I’m Brandy, what’s your name?”

“Uh, hi. I’m Quinn,” I said, glancing down at my numb hand, still held firmly in her grip.

I could see that she was tall for a woman, now that she was standing up, though that still meant she only came up to about my shoulder.

She dragged me forwards by the arm, “This is Kennocha, but everyone calls her Ken,” she said, gesturing to the elf she’d been arguing with.

Ken wore orange mage robes, though hers were cut much more loosely than Victorina’s were, and they were decorated with white trim. I was, rather guiltily, reminded of an orange creamsicle.

“This is Minki,” she continued, pointing to an absolutely tiny little elf, smaller even than Chypia was, curled up in a chair clutching a book to her chest. She had a mop of grey hair, and wore brown robes with gold trim. Like Ken’s, her robes were cut rather loosely, but from what I could see of the bits of her that poked out of her robes she was rather slim.

“She’s really quiet but she’s also super awesome to talk to if you need help with magic stuff, and this is Halea, who is a super awesome battlemage.”

Halea was sitting next to Ken, her arm propped on the armrest of the sofa, resting her chin in her hand. She reminded me a lot of Thera, just a little bit… darker. She had the same generous build, though her long hair was black instead of silver, and her eyes were violet instead of lavender.  The similarities ended at the clothes though, Thera wouldn’t have been allowed the gold robes that Halea wore, though she probably would have chosen a similar design. Except for the colours Halea’s robes matched Victorina’s, closely cut at the waist, and with a lower neckline.

“Finally,” she said, indicating a quite stocky woman, who must have been a dwarf, “This is Neferoy.”

The dwarf woman was even shorter than the rest of the group, with the possible exception of Minki, and while she didn’t have a beard, she did have her brown hair gathered in two braids that fell down her back. She didn’t seem to share the noble birth of the rest of her friends though, and instead wore simple grey mage robes that lacked any trim at all.

“Thanks, um,” I said rather stiffly, leaning slightly away from Brandy, very gently trying to get my arm out of her grip.

“Oh, sorry,” she said, releasing me.

I tried to keep my awkwardness at being pulled into the centre of the room from showing, but I got the impression that I wasn’t doing very well. I looked towards Lili for support, and saw her looking up at Victorina, smiling.

“See, it’s just like I told you, he won’t be any trouble at all,” Lili said.

“Hey! I can be plenty of trouble, weren’t you just saying how you were glad that I wasn’t going to be one of your students?”

“Well, I suppose that hope is dead now, but I suppose I can put up with you,” she said teasingly.

“Is Quinn going to join our club then?” Minki asked, in a voice that was almost a whisper.

“As long as everyone is okay with it, yes,” Victorina said.

“I don’t mind,” Minki said, her voice even quieter, if that was possible.

“Totally yes,” Brandy said, “He is like the sweetest little nerdy boy ever.”

*Good?*

“If you’re alright with him then I’m alright with him Vicky,” Neferoy said, and while she had a deep rumbly voice, she unfortunately didn’t speak in a Scottish accent.

“It’ll be fun, we never have guys over to the clubhouse, he’s even pretty cute,” Halea said, “and he’s even blushing! He’s perfect Vic.”

I could feel the heat in my face as I sat down awkwardly in the nearest empty armchair.

“Are you sure Vicky? I thought we started this club so we **wouldn’t** have any men bossing us around, no offense Quinn. It’s just we’ve worked really hard for this,” Kennocha said.

“None taken,” I said raising my hands, “I get it.”

“Besides,” Victorina added with a smile, “I’ll be the one bossing **him** around, I hope you don’t have a problem with that Quinn.”

I was about to answer, but I was interrupted by a familiarly sexy voice, “Quinn doesn’t mind having a woman on top.”

-----

My head snapped towards the door, “Thera?”

And there she was standing in the doorway, one hand resting on the frame. I couldn’t quite place it, but she looked better than the last time I’d seen her. She had some new clothes, not mage robes mind you, and they seemed to fit her better than what I’d last seen her in. She still seemed to favour pink, and she kept her hair up in a bun, just like when I’d first met her. She wore a thick leather apron over her close fit dress, and I could just make out the gleam of metal poking out of the pockets along the bottom. The apron seemed to be stained with something, and there was a smudge of something greenish on her forehead.

“Yeah, hi there Quinn,” she said, losing the dusky tone, and dipping her head a little.

“You two know each other?” Victorina said, clearly interested.

“Yeah, I was the one who found Quinn a ship to Nimre,” Thera said, not quite meeting my eyes.

“But Quinn-“ Victorina started, “Oh,” and the rest of the group seemed to pick something up from Victorina’s expression.

“Yeah,” Thera nodded.

“Wait, you mean?” Kennocha started, and there were similar mumblings of realization from the rest of the group.

I rubbed at my forehead with the back of one useless hand, “I really don’t want to talk about it. It’s not that interesting, and I’m here now, that’s all that matters.”

“If,” Kennocha started, “If that’s what you want Quinn.”

Even with my poor vision I could see the sympathetic and piteous looks I was getting, and that was the last thing I wanted.

“Excuse me,” I said, rising, “I just want to talk to Thera for a moment.”

Thera joined me just outside the small sitting room, and I shut the door behind us. There was an awkward moment, as I looked down at Thera, and she stood there hugging herself. Then she had her arms around me, and was crying into my chest. I slipped my arms around her gently, doing my best despite the numbness, to stroke her back gently. She calmed down after a moment, but didn’t pull away, and instead she stayed there leaning against my chest.

“I’m so so so so sorry Quinn. It was all my fault, I’m so sorry,” she said, and I could hear her hold back more tears.

“It wasn’t your fault Thera, you couldn’t have known,” I soothed, still stroking her back gently.

“I was the one who picked the captain, I should have known better Quinn. I should have thought more about the risks you’d be taking. And when I found out, oh Verrin I am such a coward.”

“Thera…” I started.

“I met Sila you know,” she interrupted, “She caught the same ship as I did. She was easy to pick out, I saw her wearing the bracelet I’d given you. So I made friends with her, there were a couple other passengers on the ship, but we were the only two women so we stuck together. Her father mostly left us girls alone. I didn’t tell her that I knew you at first, I just asked her where she was going and why. I barely even needed to prompt her, she really likes you, you know. I was going to tell her that I’d met you as well, but the more she talked about you… She really likes you Quinn.
