But, if you’re really so good at detecting listening enchantments I’d like to hire you to check out the clubhouse.”

“Hire me? And is Victorina going to be okay with that?” she asked, unsure.

I shrugged, “If you find bugs she hasn’t I doubt she’ll mind. I might have had someone visit me while I was in the tower, and they might have implied that there are bugs in the clubhouse. They might just be giving me the runaround, but I’d like to know for sure. And yeah, hire. I insist.”

“Oh, well if you insist your imperial highness, then I suppose I must agree,” she said, standing and bowing low to the ground, “Will your imperial highness deign to teleport us to your clubhouse, or shall I carry you.”

“Oh shut up and stand over here,” I told her, as I started concentrating on the spell.

I realized, when she came to stand next to me, that she was even shorter now than when I’d last seen her. She’d lost another couple of inches in height and couldn’t have been more than an inch or two taller than Brandy, though Nothus was still comically muscular as always.

---

There was a flicker, and we escaped the stinking dive that was Nothus’s inn, to the luxury of Victorina’s clubhouse.

The others were already up, as they too had classes to get to, and our presence was noticed pretty quickly.

“Quinn,” Minki said, from the balcony above the front hall, “You’re back!”

I could hear a door open somewhere upstairs at Minki’s exclamation, but I was distracted by the little grey mop of hair that threw itself down the stairs to thump into my stomach.

“I did say that I’d be back,” I noted wryly, as I patted her on the back.

“Well,” she said, “I was worried. I was expecting you to be back sooner, you might have missed your class if you were any later,” she sniffed, and took a step back ,”You’re all smelly and dirty. What were you doing?”

“It’s a secret,” I replied secretively.

“And you’ve brought Nothus,” came Victorina’s level voice from the balcony above, and I could hear the unspoken question in her voice.

*Is this who you’ve been with since running away?*

“Quinn’s hired me to check for magical listening enchantment,” Nothus replied, and I was sure from the overly diplomatic tone she used that she’d picked up on *exactly* what was going on between Victorina and I.

“Is that a problem?” Nothus finished.

“No,” Victorina allowed, “And you think that there are such enchantments, Quinn?”

“I had a visitor while I was away,” I explained, “They may just have intended to rattle me, but they did know things that they shouldn’t have.”

Victorina nodded in understanding, but otherwise kept quiet.

“Go get washed up and ready for class Quinn,” Minki said, “I can babysit Nothus while she has a walk around.”

“Thanks Minki,” I said, ruffling her hair on the way by.

“Hey!” she protested, and I dodged her flailing arms as I escaped to my room.

---

I hadn’t even been in been in my room for a full minute before there was a tapping on the door.

“Come in Victorina,” I said.

She opened the door and stepped through quietly, before closing it gently behind her.

We were both quiet for a long while, as we stood there looking at each other from either side of the room. I was deep into *very* unfamiliar territory, it was not often that I was the one to end a relationship.

*Not often? This is the first time.*

Before when things had come to an end I had known that it was my own doing. I rarely knew what it was that I’d done, but there was never any doubt that it *was* my own doing. Of course, that didn’t make it hurt any less with Victorina. In fact, it probably hurt more.

*Betrayal, now that’s a new one.*

“Is there anything left to be said?” she asked finally.

“Not really.”

“Will you stay?” she asked.

“With the club? Yes.”

“But not with me.”

“No. I’m sorry.”

She looked away, unwilling to meet my gaze, “You really did trust me completely didn’t you?”

“Yeah,” I said, though it came out as a rasp.

“I’m sorry.”

“I know,” I said sadly.

“Thank you for staying Quinn,” she said finally, “It’s good having you here, even if...” she trailed off.

“It’s like I told you before Victorina,” I said, “I owe you a great deal. What you did doesn’t change that, not one bit. I’m not going anywhere any time soon, and you’re still my friend, even if that’s all it is between us.”

She nodded, “And your plan? Did you get what you needed?”

“Yeah,” I nodded, “We can talk more once Nothus has done her sweep.”

“Alright,” she said, turning to the door, a little too quickly, “Ah, you and Nothus?”

“Are just friends.”

“Like you and I,” she said, a little bitterly.

“Exactly like that.”

---

“So Nothus?” I asked, as I joined her and the others in the sitting room a little while later.

“I found the enchantments,” she explained, “There was only two of them. One right there,” she said, pointing to the balcony doors, “And another on the front door.”

“Dammit,” Halea swore, “I should have thought of that.”

“What?” I asked.

“It’s not actually that hard to detect listening enchantments,” Nothus explained, “Not when they’re out in the open, and not if you’re a Mage. All you really need to do is look for places where the ambient mana is being drawn in, without some other obvious enchantment in place to explain the drain.”

“So what the Tanakas did was mask the enchantment within the *much* more mana intensive defensive enchantments around each of the doors,” Halea finished.

“And the doors are particularly thickly enchanted?” I asked, “Couldn’t they have more placed along the walls or something?”

Nothus shook her head, “Not really, the doors draw a lot more mana. There’s enchantments to control who can come and go, switching enchantments to allow the door to open while keeping the defences up, and all manner of other enchantments that are placed on only the doors and nothing else.”

“Windows?”

“I checked them too, but those don’t draw quite as much mana as the doors so it’s harder to hide things,” Nothus shook her head, “There’s nothing there.”

“Thank you Nothus,” Victorina said, “I don’t suppose...”

“You’re welcome,” Nothus said, “But no. I’m fine on my own.”

“Well then,” I said, “I’ll be back after class, Victorina, Minki, and I’ll let you two know just what the hell it is I’ve got planned.”

“Do I get to know what the hell it is you’ve got planned?” Nothus asked.

“Nope! But you can be sure that I’ll brag about it afterwards.”

---

I had to do a double take the first time I saw Mata, the ‘new’ Mata that is, sitting with Diova and company in our Spell Invention class.

Take Victorina for example, she was gorgeous, and *very* generously proportioned. If she was human, she would have been an example of the absolute limit of what a human woman could ever naturally achieve.

Halea, well now she was a bit past that limit, but not too far. If Victorina had movie star proportions, then Halea had porn star proportions. There was some clear artificiality going on there, but it was still tastefully done. She didn’t look absurd for example.

Mata, she looked absurd. Maybe elven views on such things were different, and I was reminded briefly of the cultural differences between even Victorina and I, but to me she just looked grotesque. Mata looked like she had a couple of watermelons shoved up the front of her robes, and whatever potion or enchantment she’d taken must have rearranged some of her internal organs and restructured her rib cage, since there was no way in hell that any sort of corset was going to narrow her waist *that* much.

*Is she even going to be able to speak with her lips all puffy like that? Fucking hell Diova.*

Maybe I shouldn’t have been surprised. I was dealing of course with a society that showed wealth and opulence by plastering everything in gold leaf. It only made sense that such people would modify their toys in the same way.

“Quinn, have you heard the good news?” Diova asked, as I sat down across from him.

“I suppose that depends on what the news is,” I said, glancing at Baron Bronippo, who along with Tosa, was also at the table.

“The professor has said that there was a discussion in the battle magic department. Once we get Solar Pulse polished up they’ll be adding it to the curriculum immediately.”

“Damn, that is good news,” I agreed, “Also, you’re welcome.”

Diova raised an eyebrow, but didn’t comment.

“What have you got for us once we’re done with Solar Pulse then?” Tosa asked.

“Oh, a few ideas. I wanted to try an enchantment actually, we should be able to make a half decent horseless carriage.”

“Isn’t there already an existing enchantment that can be used to make a wheel or axle turn?” the Baron asked, “I think that’s been done before, it never really works out very well either. The creations are nearly undrivable.”

“We’d be modifying the enchantment, as we did with Solaris to turn it into Solar Pulse. All the existing enchantment does is rotate the axle or what have you at a constant rate, and that’s not what we want.”

“It’s not?” Mata asked, the words thick in her mouth as she tried to talk around her comically large lips.

“Nope,” I confirmed, “I mean, we could put a clutch or some other gearing arrangement between the enchantment and the wheels, but then we’re losing mana efficiency. Better to make the enchantment itself work, rather than try to kludge together a solution that would make the existing one work at the task.”

“And aside from that,” Diova added, “We wouldn’t get any credit for working with the *existing* enchantment.”

“Exactly,” I agreed, “I do want to get to Solar Pulse today, but I’ll sketch out the general idea,” I said, as I pulled a pad of paper towards me.

“The main thing we would need,” I began, “Is a way to vary the rate of rotation...”

---

The conversation with Victorina didn't take long at all, mostly because I didn’t tell her much that she didn’t already know. I needed her, but like Nothus, I’d only need her for what came after I claimed the guild hall. I needed Victorina to help me manage the political side of things, mainly in and around Azarburg. What was the political situation like in the city? Who mattered, and why did they matter? Did they pay taxes to the University, or just tribute to Nezzabi? It was one big mess, but one that Victorina was well suited to solving, so that was her task.

Nothus, well, I didn’t really have a task in mind for her, but I knew that I wanted her on the team. She seemed overly solitary, even to me, but there had to be something that I could offer her to get her to come on board.

And the last of the three was Minki. I’d originally intended for her task to fall to Victorina, but after the events of the past few days, I realized that I couldn’t trust Victorina as much as I thought I could. Minki would be the one to ensure that my claim to the guild hall was upheld. She’d enter the claim at the given time, ideally only seconds after the curse was lifted, naming me as the guild hierarch. She’d also ensure that any loopholes and counter-claims were defended against.

“But isn’t Kennocha the one who normally does all this sort of thing?” she asked, after I’d finished telling her what I needed from her, “She knows all about administering things. She does all the paperwork for the club, handles all the bills, everything. What if I mess it up?” she worried.

I knelt down in front of her, “I need someone I can trust to do this Minki, and I’ve got to be able to trust them completely. I do trust Kennocha, I really do. But not completely, not when there’s this much on the line. And Victorina, well, I’m guessing you know now how that went.”

She nodded slightly, “Yeah,” she whispered.

“It’s got to be you.”

She nodded again, “Alright Quinn, I’ll do it.”

---

“So what’s the plan for today then?” Nothus asked, a couple days later and after we’d met up at our Healing class.

“Well, I’ve been thinking about you, and I’ve had some interesting ideas.”

“Oh? Late at night, when you’re alone, thinking of me?”

“Exactly,” I laughed, “I know you’ve been looking for new ways to make yourself stronger, without just turning yourself into a living mountain, and I’ve got a couple of suggestions.”

“So, you’re only interested in me for my body then?” she laughed.

“Basically, come on, we’ll find a place to eat, and I’ll tell you about a Canadian hero.”

---

“Metal claws?” she asked incredulously, as she was mid way through a mountain of food.

“So you can stab people and stuff,” I said, waving my hands around in vague slashing gestures.

“Stab people and stuff,” she recited, eyebrow raised.

“Or threaten people with stabbing,” I offered placatingly, “You’re skeptical, I get that. Let's table the metal claws discussion for now, and move on to a different awesome idea I’ve had.”

“Please,” she said in an amused tone, “Continue.”

“Carbon nanotubes.”

She sighed, “What?”

“Diamond,” I paused, “Bones.”

“Diamond bones?”

“Well, sort of. Carbon nanotubes are better actually, you wouldn’t need to worry about them shattering. Imagine,” I said, “Super strong and super light bones.”

“That does sound better than the claws thing,” she admitted.

“You might be able to apply the same theories to your muscles as well to increase your muscle density, but I’m a lot less sure about that one.”

“Explain it to me then. And maybe, *maybe* we can look into the metal claws afterwards,” she promised.



# Chapter 67

**Halea**

---

“Haven’t we got anything bigger than that?” I asked.

Neferoy rolled her eyes, “Of course you’d be the one to find the size somehow inadequate.”

I shrugged, “I know what I like.”

Minki, who had turned a little pink, shook her head, “The two largest bases we found were for twelve point manastones, and we’ve already sold those, along with the extra ten point stones.”

“Was it not worth it for us to keep the twelve point stones?” I asked.

“Not really,” Neferoy replied, “If I lead an enchanting circle with the whole club, we’ve got a ten point stone for everyone. Including an extra helper, if we can find someone else to join us. All we’d gain by swapping two people’s stones out for twelve pointers is four mana. It’s not enough to matter.”

“So how much mana can we muster up at any one time then?” I asked distractedly, as I hovered the teapot over from the sideboard to refill my cup.

“About one sixty, to one seventy. Depends mostly on whether we catch Quinn when he’s fresh,” Neferoy replied.

“I think I might be able to contribute a little more than I have been doing,” Minki provided, “I’ve been practising with using my enervation to cast spells.”

“Really?” Neferoy asked, her bushy eyebrows raised, “I can’t say that you’re the first person I’d think of to try that sort of thing.”

Minki shrugged, “Ever since Quinn and Nothus... did what they did for me, I’ve felt a lot more energetic. I don’t get tired as easily, and I don’t feel so winded when I need to walk somewhere in the city. I haven’t had a chance to re-test my abilities, but I’d guess that I’ve got about as much enervation as Brandy does now.”

“That’s great news Minki,” Neferoy said, “I suppose the events leading up to the new you might not have been terribly pleasant, but I don’t think I’m the only one who’s noticed how much more comfortable you seem with yourself now.”

It was more than just being more comfortable in her own body, Minki *looked* different now. The changes were quite subtle, but they were noticeable to anyone who had more than a passing acquaintance with her.

It called to mind the difference between what a person actually looked like, and how you might remember them. Little details tend to get amplified, especially if you’ve not seen the person in question for some time. Someone tall might be a little taller when seen only in your mind’s eye, or the colour of their hair or eyes a little more vivid. You remember not the person, but a caricature of the person, built by your memories.

*And Minki, she looks just like that caricature.*

There was a sudden shock, like some combination of a cold bucket of water being dumped over my head, and a loud and discordant note.

It took me a moment to shake it off, and I was left with an uncomfortable shudder running down my spine.

“Agh, that was damned unpleasant,” Neferoy said, as she hunched her shoulders against the odd sensation that the wave of dischordant magic left in it’s wake.

“Felt like it came from somewhere behind the clubhouse,” I noted, as I stood and walked to the balcony doors at the rear of the sitting room.

“Oh!” Minki exclaimed, “Do you think it was Quinn? He was back there working on his rifle.”

“I doubt it,” I said, “That was a pretty sizable Mishap. Quinn’s a better Mage than that.”

“He might have just gotten unlucky, Halea,” Neferoy warned.

“Maybe,” I granted, “But I don’t think that even Quinn is *that* unlucky. I’ll check on him though, let him know what that was at least. That’s probably the first time he’ll have felt anything like it.”

I pushed open the doors and stepped out onto the balcony, and took a look around before returning inside.

“Anything?” Neferoy asked.

“Didn’t see him, I’ll go down and look around. Besides, it’s about time for supper. Maybe if I bat my eyelashes at him he’ll make us something to eat.”

---

Quinn’s things were still lying on the patio table he’d appropriated for his work, and while it looked as if he’d just stepped away, I couldn’t find him anywhere nearby.

*I really hope he didn’t vaporize himself. I’d have a hard time explaining that to Victorina.*

I sat down at the table, and had a little poke around. His ‘rifle’ seemed mostly to be a brass tube, with some wood furnishings that reminded me of the stock of a crossbow. There was a large opening where one of the large boxy ‘magazines’ might fit, though Quinn hadn’t left any of the boxy creations in his weapon. There were several strewn across the top of the table though, all in varying states of completion.

*A little underwhelming if you ask me. I would have expected something more complicated than a brass tube with a bit of wood nailed to it, and a box with a spring inside.*

But that was Outsiders for you, some of their most valuable information was so simple as to be scarcely unbelievable once you grew to understand it.

I heard a little skittering sound under the table, and gave a start. I pushed my chair back, knocking it over in my haste to get to my feet, and took several steps back.

*Dangerous heroines are not afraid of mice Halea. Calm down.*

I stood the chair back up, and then knelt down, a safe distance away, to peer under the table. The grass under it hadn’t been cut, and was five or six inches tall, which served well to hide whatever tiny animal had taken shelter under Quinn’s work area.

*Are humans afraid of mice? Do they even have mice on Earth?*

The grass stirred slightly in the breeze, but I didn’t notice anything move out of turn.

*This is boring.*

“BOO!” I shouted, slapping my hands on the ground.

Something indistinct and dark blue jumped up at the loud noise, and I heard a tiny voice shout, “Fuck!”

“Quinn?” I chortled.

“Oh for fucks sake,” the voice said again, and a moment later, Quinn was pushing his way out of the shoulder high forest of grass.

“Oh, I have got to show the others,” I cried, as I reached to scoop him up, “They’re going to *love* this.”

He tried to dart away, but I caught him gently by the back of his robes, and dropped him into the palm of my hand.

“I hate you so much right now.”

It was definitely Quinn, but much *much* shorter. He was maybe three inches tall, but otherwise seemed none the worse for wear.

“Maybe Minki’s got some little dolly clothes we can dress you up in,” I cooed.

It was hard to tell, since Quinn wasn’t even the length of one of my fingers, but it looked an awful lot like Quinn was bright red.

“Halea, please,” he said, “You can’t let the others see me like this.”

“Why not?” I laughed, “It’s not fair if I’m the only one who gets to enjoy this.”

I heard the click of the clubhouse door opening, followed by Victorina’s voice, “Halea, you find Quinn?”

“And you certainly can’t let *her* see me like this,” Quinn hissed.

“Fine,” I huffed, before dropping him down the front of my robes, which elicited a whispered protest from Quinn, “Now don’t you move around too much, or the others will notice. No,” I called out, raising my voice, “He’s not back here.”

I felt Quinn squirming around a little as I turned away from the table and climbed the steps back up to the clubhouse, but if Victorina noticed something odd, she didn’t let it show.

“You just get back?” I asked.

Victornia nodded, “I was hoping that there might be supper waiting, I’m starving.”

“He’s been spending a lot of time on that new weapon of his, I imagine he’s out getting more of whatever it is he needs to work on it.”

“That Mishap the others mentioned then, that wasn’t him?”

I shook my head, “I got out there pretty quick, I would have sensed if the epicentre was somewhere in the back garden. Why, are you worried about him?”

She opened her mouth to speak, before stopping herself and shaking her head in resignation.

I stopped, just at the foot of the stairs that lead back up to the sitting room, and she drew up short, “You still care about him?” I asked quietly.

She nodded sadly, “I just wanted to be sure, do you know what I mean?” she asked, “Quinn seemed so genuine, and when we had our little dominance games, it was just a bit of flirty fun, and not an attempt by him to gain some sort of control over me. But...”

“You’ve been burned before,” I grimaced, “Yeah, I remember.”

“And then,” she continued, “By trying to *make sure*, I just sarded the whole thing up.”

“Think you can fix it?” I asked.

“No,” she said sadly, “Quinn and I talked... It didn’t last long, but it didn’t really need to. He’s never going to trust me again, not as he once did, and I couldn’t bear going on like that. Not when I’d be thinking every minute of how it used to be between us.”

“Well, if you’d like my unsolicited advice,” I told her, “The best thing to do is get blind drunk, and then throw yourself at the first warm body that’s not going to get you knocked up.”

“Is that how you normally get over a breakup?” she laughed, though I could see she was trying to hold back a few stray tears.

“I’m exaggerating of course, but only slightly,” I said, taking her gently by the shoulders, “Go fall into bed with someone cute. You’ll feel better, and it’ll be a lot easier to move on afterwards. I don’t think Quinn’s  going anywhere any time soon, and you’re going to need to be able to keep working together in a professional manner, without letting the baggage between the two of you get in the way. And,” I continued, “You’ve also got to be able to deal with the fact that you’re not the only one that’s going to be hopping into bed with someone else.”

“You among them?” she asked, though thankfully she sounded exasperated, rather than territorial.

I shrugged, and felt Quinn slip a little further down as I did, “I might let him get all up in this,” I smirked.

“I suppose I shouldn’t be surprised,” she laughed sadly, and stepped into my arms, to give me a quick hug, “Thanks for talking to me Halea.”

“You’re welcome,” I told her, patting her gently on the back.

“Alright,” she said, stepping away, and visibly centring herself, “Now, enough of this nonsense. We’re going out to eat, and Quinn can take care of his own silly self.”

“I would love to join you, but I’ve got an assignment due Louday and I’ve barely started. Next time,” I promised.

She gave me a look that seemed somehow motherly in its disappointment, *I suppose we’re done with the sisterly talk then.*

“Its fine,” I said defensively, “It’s for battlemagic, I’ll probably be done before you get back.”

“Well enjoy your time to work alone then. The rest of us,” she said, “Will be off at dinner.”

*Yes, definitely motherly.*

----

I pushed the door shut with my foot, and slipped a hand down the front of my robes to retrieve Quinn. I snagged the hood of his robes, and lifted him up to dangle at eye level.

“You know,” he squeeked, retaining a surprising amount of dignity, “I’m really glad it’s been a cool couple of days.”

I raised one elegant eyebrow, “I am a lady,” I said haughtily, “I do not sweat.”

“Well I certainly appreciate that, your ladyship. Now, how the hell do I fix this?”

I carried him over to my desk, and set him down on it, “I’ve no idea really. It’s not permanent at least,” I assured him, “I know that for sure, but not much else.”

“For sure, for sure?” he asked, “Shouldn’t it have worn off already if it’s not permanent? I didn’t put that much energy into the spell, and I didn’t cast it as an enchantment.”

I pulled the chair out and sat down, resting my chin on my interlaced fingers.

“Mishaps don’t work like normal spells,” I explained, “I’m probably not the best person to explain it, you’d want to ask Lili or maybe Neferoy, but from what I understand, Mishaps can draw in more than the normal amount of ambient mana. So it will wear off,” I promised, “But it could take a while.”

He sat down and took off his spectacles to rub at his face, “How long is ‘a while’?” he asked.

“The *longest* I’ve ever heard of a Mishap lasting is a week-”

“A week!”

“Probably only a couple of hours though,” I finished.

“I suppose I can deal with that,” he grumbled.

I reached out, and pet the top of his head with one finger, “What were you even doing out there Quinn?”

He bat ineffectually at my tree trunk like finger, but eventually resigned himself to his fate, “Magazines are dumb,” he said simply.

“Is that so?”

He nodded his widdle head, *oh he’s just so cute,* “The gun itself is simple. Incredibly simple. It’s a pipe with a bomb and a bit of lead in it. Set off the bomb, and the bit of lead goes flying at whoever it is you don’t like. I mean, it’s reductive, but that’s really all there is to it. The hard part is setting off the bomb in a controlled manner. My Uncle is using a simple matchlock, which basically amounts to burning wick on a lever. My gun is a bit more complicated since it’s bolt action and uses a striker, but even then, I managed to make a working version *without* Reshape, once I’d gotten it right the first time.”

“How is the magazine giving you so much trouble then?” I asked, “And how exactly does any of this result in your currently reduced stature?”

“Oh, I’d just gotten fed up with trying to make the magazines work, and had moved on to experimenting with shrinking down one of my guns. I actually got it working. Well... mostly,” he hedged, gesturing down at himself, “As you can see, there are some issues.”

“You were using your modified version of the spell?" I asked.

“Yeah,” he grimaced, “Hopefully it was bad luck, and not something endemic to the modifications I made.”

I shrugged, “Show it to Lili, she’ll be able to give you an idea of how you might fix it, if it even needs fixing.”

He flopped back on the desk, resting his head in his hands, “That’s probably a good idea.”

I drummed my fingers on the desk, “Do you think you can make the magazine work? Once you get back to full size, that is.”

“Probably not,” he said honestly, “The issue is the springs. The magazines work at first, for the first... oh, couple dozen rounds. Then you start to get feeding issues, which get worse and worse as you go on.”

“Feeding?” I asked.

“The process of getting the cartridge out of the magazine and into the chamber,” he clarified, “It needs to be smooth, and if the spring in the magazine doesn’t lift the cartridge up high enough, or lifts it too high, then it doesn’t go in smoothly.”

“Mmm, and it *must* go in smoothly.”

He snorted, “Yeah, and if it doesn’t, the gun can get jammed up. It’s manageable at first if you’re careful, though its much less than ideal. It becomes completely unusable very quickly though. I don’t know enough about metallurgy to make spring steel, and none of what I can find or make otherwise with bronze or copper is likely to do the trick.”

“Couldn’t you just replace the magazines once they get worn out though?” I asked, “You’ve got Reshape, it wouldn’t be hard for you to recycle the metal. Even if you can only use it a few times before its no good, you’re not going to be using your rifle that much, not when it’s only a backup for your magic. I mean, it’s not like you’re trying to outfit an army.”

Quinn, was suddenly very quiet.

*Oh.*

“Quinn...” I said hesitantly, “I don’t suppose this has anything to do with the way you disappeared for a couple of days the other week?”

“Uh, nope. Certainly not.”

“And when you were asking Neferoy about how you might go about accumulating a couple hundred mana, that’s also entirely unrelated?

“Exactly.”

“Why does it feel like there’s something significant you’re not telling me?”

He sat up, and gave me a long and thoughtful look, before letting his gaze fall back to the table. Which for him, was the floor.

“I’m playing this one pretty close to the chest Halea. Only two other people know what I’m planning, and even then, they’re both missing pieces of the puzzle. Once I reach the next step, I’ll be able to tell everyone in the club, but I’m keeping it to myself until then.”

“Victorina and Minki?” I guessed.

He shrugged.

“I understand.”

“Thanks,” he said simply.

I leaned my chair back on two legs and let out a long breath. *Just what is it that he’s got Minki into?*

“You know,” Quinn said, a moment later, “This is the part where I’d normally make some excuse to leave, before going off to hide in the library, but that’s kinda difficult when I’m too small to turn the pages.”

“Can’t you just Apport the pages?” I asked lazily.

“Tried that,” he said, “Well, not quite with pages. Regardless, the strength of Apportation seems to be proportional to my reduced size. Being three inches tall is not terribly convenient.”

“Well,” I grinned, still staring up at the ceiling, “I think I can find some way to keep you entertained until the enchantment wears off. Maybe you’d like me to stuff you back down my robes?” I asked, “Or, mmm, yes. I can think of a few interesting places that you’d fit.”

I looked back down at the table, to see Quinn already on his feet and sprinting for the far edge.

He narrowly avoided a swipe of one massive hand as he leapt from the table, and by the time I’d gotten out of the chair and around to the other side of the desk he was already on the floor and running for the bed.

“You’ll never catch me Becky!” he shouted.

I bent down to swipe at him, but just as I was about to get my hands on him he cast Leap, and flew free of my clutching fingers.

Rather than swipe at him while he was in the air, and risk hurting him, I pounced on him the moment he landed. I caught him in a cage of my fingers, but gingerly, as if he were a butterfly or glow bug. But unlike butterflies and glow bugs, Quinn could teleport.

“Hey!” I protested, when he reappeared just under the bed, “Teleportation is cheating.”

“It’s only fair,” he shouted back, “I haven’t even got a Zooper Car, and you’re all big!”

“Big? You think I’m *big*?” I said with pantomime fury, though my giggling probably spoiled the effect, “I’m going to catch you, and then you’re going to tell me who the hell Becky is.”

----

We kept up our little game of cat and mouse throughout my bedroom and the rest of the clubhouse for at least a couple of hours, until Quinn’s Mishap finally ran through the supply of ambient mana it had picked up. The two of us were left tired and panting on the floor in the library, because of course it was the library, this was Quinn we’re talking about.

“I thought ladies didn’t sweat,” he teased, as I mopped at by brow with the sleeve of my robes.

“Oh hush, I would have thought that your human endurance would have handled this better,” I shot back, “But you look like a wreck.”

“I ran a lot further than you did,” he retorted.

“No you didn’t,” I challenged, “I was running around the same clubhouse that you were.”

“Sure,” he allowed, “But it’s a matter of scale. Imagine if it was the clubhouse that had grown, rather than one of us shrinking. Each step in the stairs would the height of a two storey building, and the clubhouse would be almost a mile across.”

“Fine,” I huffed, “I defer to your superior math skills.”

I lifted my head from the floor, to peer at him sitting with his back against one of the bookshelves.

“The others aren't back yet,” I noted.

“Nope,” he agreed.

“It’s late,” I pointed out

“It is,” he agreed.

We were both quiet for a moment, and then I lay back and let out a sigh, “Not tonight though.”

“Not tonight,” he agreed.


# Chapter 68

**Quinn**

---

*Is there an easy way to pull three hundred mana out of thin air? Of course not Quinn, if there were, everyone would do it.*

It had been about a week and a half since my return from the tower, and while I’d learned the spells I’d need for my plan, there were other problems.

The first of which was the mana. I now knew the exact enchantment that the Ariros guild members had used nearly a thousand years ago, which theoretically meant that I knew how to dispel it. The problem was a matter of speed. It was only thirty mana to dispel the enchantment, but with the large manastone we made from the crystals retrieved from the cave, that was totally something I could manage. But not quickly. It would take at least an hour and a half to dispel the enchantment the ‘normal’ way, and I didn’t have anywhere near that time. I could afford to let the wraith take a bite out of me, in fact, the plan pretty much required it, but an hour and a half of that was far more than I’d be able to endure.

I could cut down the casting time drastically by using a spell stone, but that had its own troubles. Yes, it would cast the spell effectively instantaneously as long as it had been prepared properly, but it was not cheap. If you wanted to cast a spell worth one mana, you needed to put ten mana in to actually construct the spell stone.

*Which means, I need to find 300 mana somewhere, or find some way to survive an hour and a half of the wraith’s attention.*

“I guess you haven’t figured out the solution to your mystery problem yet?” Nothus asked, startling me back to reality.

The two of us had found a quiet corner of the Library to work in, and she was just now rejoining me after having spent a little while wandering around and gathering more research material.

“Is it that obvious?” I asked, as she set down a stack of books on the desk.

“Pretty sure I don’t need to be an empath to recognize when you can’t find the solution to a problem,” she teased, “You tend to get all grumbly.”

“Well that’s the problem. I actually do have a solution. It’s just a terrible one,” I grumbled, *spend soul, and by doing so, waste the extra 700 energy that wasn’t consumed by the spell stone.*

“Maybe you just need to relax, work on something else for a while, or just pay more attention to your classes,” she suggested.

“I pay plenty of attention to my classes,” I retorted, “And I doubt I’ll find the solution there.”

“Do you really?” she smiled, “Besides, that’s not really what I mean. When you’re having trouble with a problem you tend to go work on something else for a while, and come back to it. But I’m pretty sure you’ve been stewing over this, whatever *this* is, for weeks now. Go do something else, I’m sure it can wait Quinn.”

I shrugged, “Maybe you’re right. I’ve still got to get Solar Pulse finished up, and there’s supposed to be a couple of team matches in the Arena with my battle magic class that I could be preparing for.”

“See, that sounds perfect,” she said encouragingly, “And if you can’t come up with a solution after all of that, then I suppose you could resort to elf sacrifice or something.”

*...now that’s not a terrible idea...*

“Quinn,” she said, suddenly very serious, “You know that was a joke, right?”

“What? Oh, of course,” I said reassuringly, “I wasn’t thinking about elf sacrifice at all.”

She gave me a flat look, “Empath, remember?”

“Empath, but not mind reader,” I agreed, “But you should be able to sense that when I say I’m not planning on sacrificing any elves, that’s it’s the truth.”

“I can also tell that you’re being deceptive,” she said knowingly, “Just... Try not to get yourself expelled.”

“Yes mom,” I said in my best rebellious teenager voice, but she just rolled her eyes, “What about the carbon nanotube thing I showed you, have you been able to make any use of that?”

“Oh, you have no idea,” she said, grinning widely, “The first time I woke up after doing the switch, replacing my muscle fibres and strengthening my bones like you suggested,” she clarified, “I accidentally tore the door off of its hinges when I went to go down for breakfast. I haven’t even replaced everything yet, I’m still mostly an elf/human hybrid, since I want to take the time to get used to it gradually. I don’t want to accidentally tear off someone’s arm when I shake their hand.”

“That’s great,” I congratulated her, “And I guess it explains why you’ve kept downsizing. You probably don’t really need the mass any more.”

She was probably a little under six feet now, though she’d still be confused for a man by anyone that didn’t know of her. Her hair, previously worn back in a loose ponytail, was now cut short like mine, which set her apart from most of the elf women who preferred to keep theirs long. She was still thickly muscled, and entirely flat chested, which when combined with her bullet like head made her look every bit like The Rock. A slightly smaller Rock though, as she had slimmed down a bit from the extreme levels she’d been at when she was still seven feet tall.

She nodded, though I caught something *off* about the way she averted her gaze, “I’ve been slimming down a little as well, dropping most of my mass as I slowly replace what I keep with the nanotubes. I couldn’t quite replace my bones entirely, but even with the reinforcements I’ve been able to make, I’m pretty sure they’re mostly indestructible.”

“I wonder if the Arena has rules about that sort of thing,” I mused, “Could you just rush the guy and punch him?”

“I don’t know, maybe,” she said absently, “Um, you know what, I’ve got some errands to run,” she explained, as she stood up, “I might be back a while later, if you’re still here.”

“Oh, I’ll be here for a while,” I assured her, “If not, you might find me down at the cafe across the street.”

-----

I must have fallen asleep at some point, because it had grown dark by the time I woke up. There was little light coming in through the windows, and the small study area was lit only by the single oil lantern that sat on the table. It too had burned down, and cast the whole area in a flickering orange light.

I reached over and turned the wheel that adjusted the length of the wick, making a mental note to enchant a portable light whenever I got the chance.

*Or just buy one I guess.*

I heard muffled footsteps approaching, quieted by the carpet that covered the floors, and looked up expecting to see Nothus.

It was not Nothus.

It was instead, a *very* beautiful young elf. *Or young looking at least.* Her messy dark grey hair, along with the way that she was shyly peeking around the bookshelf, reminded me of Minki. This elf was taller though, if only a little, and while she had the same grey eyes, she didn’t have Minki’s generally rumpled look.

“Are you Quinn?” she asked, in a soft and hopeful voice.

It made her sound almost naive or pleading, which could very well mean that she actually was in fact a young and not just young *looking* elf.

*Either that, or she had her age frozen before she even turned seventeen.*

“Yeah,” I said, taking off my glasses and rubbing sleep out of my eyes, “Why, can I help you?”

“Um, maybe,” she said, taking a furtive step forwards, “Or, maybe I can help you?”

“Oh?” I asked, more than a little confused.

“I heard that you were the one who came up with the new version of Solaris,” she said, coming closer still, and looking me dead in the eyes.

I nodded, “Yeah, that was me.”

“Well I think it’s really good, what you’re doing,” she said, really quite close now, “I think you’re a hero.”

I swallowed, “That’s, uh, very kind of you,” I said, leaning back a little.

“My family was attacked by vampires once,” she whispered, “Maybe if there were more men like *you* around back then, they would never have needed to worry.”

She placed one knee on my chair just between my legs, and leaned in rather close, her huge grey eyes filling my whole field of view.

“Maybe someone ought to show you some gratitude,” she whispered into my ear, before wrapping one arm around my neck and drawing me into a passionate kiss.

Her presence was overwhelming, and made it hard to form a coherent thought. I felt one of her hands slip into the front of my robe and go prowling around, and I found myself responding rather positively to her touch.

She pulled back finally, giving me a chance to come up for air, but she kept her face just inches from mine. Her huge grey eyes staring into mine.

“Come on,” she said in her innocent, pleading, voice, “Let’s go somewhere quiet, and I can show you just how grateful I am.”

My thoughts came thick and slow, and I was fairly sure that my brain wasn’t the one at the controls at the moment. It had been nearly two weeks since I’d had anyone in my bed, and while I’d been used to *much* less frequent feminine attention back on Earth, I’d grown used to it here on Elardia. It wasn’t as if she were unwilling either, hell, she’d come looking for me.

*She came looking for me? Oh... oh fuck.*

The sudden return to reality was like a pane of glass shattering, unfortunately, it seemed as if she’d recognized it too.

The chair fell back as I tried to push myself away from her, and my hand came up, already halfway through the gesture for Solar Pulse.

I was too slow though, much too slow, and much too weak. Hell, I’d have been too slow and too weak if she’d been nothing more than an elf, but she wasn’t an elf.

She followed me down as the chair toppled backwards, wrapping her legs around my hips, and pinning my arms to the floor with her super-elven strength. She opened her jaws wide, revealing glistening white fangs, before plunging them into my neck.



# Chapter 69

**Quinn**

---

The sudden return to reality was like a pane of glass shattering, unfortunately, it seemed as if she’d recognized it too.

The chair fell back as I tried to push myself away from her, and my hand came up, already halfway through the gesture for Solar Pulse.

I was too slow though, much too slow, and much too weak. Hell, I’d have been too slow and too weak if she’d been nothing more than an elf, but she wasn’t an elf.

She followed me down as the chair toppled backwards, wrapping her legs around my hips, and pinning my arms to the floor with her super-elven strength. She opened her jaws wide, revealing glistening white fangs, before plunging them into my neck.

She wrapped a hand around each of mine, and I felt something crack as her crushing grip forced my fingers into a fist. I could still speak to cast a spell, but most of what I knew required my hands to direct the spell in at least some capacity.

I thrashed around, trying to pull one of my hands loose, or even to just get one of my fingers uncurled. She was just too strong though, and with every second that passed I felt myself growing weaker and weaker.

That was the trouble with casting from enervation or vitality, I had plenty of both, but you didn’t just lose them by casting spells. I was hemorrhaging both, *heh, hemorrhaging,* and was quickly running out of time to come up with a solution.

*This is going to suck*

I shouted the incantation to Fire Bolt, and poured in what enervation I could spare. There was a flash of light from the corner of my eye and an *indescribable* pain as heat like the inside of a forge washed over me.

The vampire screeched and pulled back, clutching her hand that was now not much more than a smoking and blackened ruin of bone.

“KILL HIM!”

*Oh fuck, there’s more?*

I didn’t have a whole lot of time, even without her gnawing on my neck, I could feel my strength waning. There were still two big holes in my neck, and I could feel hot blood running down at an alarming rate.

I brought my good hand up, the other one I didn’t dare to look at, and fired a Solar Pulse directly into her chest. I couldn’t afford to put much power into it, but then, I didn’t need to. The rapid pulses of pure sunlight bored a hole right through her chest, and she fell limp to the floor.

I heard running feet and the clatter of furniture as I pushed her body off of mine and got to my feet. Even the strain of standing almost put me right back on my ass, and I had to lean against the bookshelf for a precious second while my vision stopped swimming.

I was brought back to reality by a book landing on my head, and I looked up to see several more cascading down. One of the freakish creatures was climbing over to get at me, and I looked back to the entrance to the little study area to see three more come pelting around the corner.

If not for the inch long fangs and the too wild eyes that made it look as if they were on something, they might have been mistaken for normal students.

*Oh fuck, Mage vampires? Nope. Nope nope nope.*

“*GOODBYE*” I shouted, as I finished the gesture that would cast Teleport.

-----

Even with the large manastone I normally used for enchanting, I didn’t get far. The main limitation was how long I had to concentrate on the spell ahead of time, and since that was less than a second, the distance I could cover was measured in metres instead of kilometres. It was a lot of metres, I was dumping nearly ten mana into the spell after all, but that could only do so much.

I’d been aiming for the lobby, for one of the balconies that ringed the large open space that served alternatively as either a display area for more interesting pieces in the Library’s collection, or as a place for events to be held.

Unfortunately, my aim was just a *little*off. I came out at the right height for the balcony, but I was about a metre to the side. Rather than reappear on the balcony, I snapped back into reality in the open space over the stairs.

I landed on my feet, but landed hard, stumbled, and then tumbled forwards. I kept my crippled hand tucked into my body as I felt, and tried my best to keep my head from knocking against anything too hard with the other.

I clattered to a stop at the bottom of the stairs, aching everywhere. If the wounds on my neck or hands were notable, it was only in that they hurt *slightly more* than everything else. I caught a glimpse of my blackened left hand as I tried to right myself, I’d landed face down with my feet up on the stairs behind me, and almost retched. I tore my gaze away as quickly as I could, and focused on my manastone ring.

Not the one that bore the stone I’d used for the teleport, no, this was the one I’d gotten all those months ago back in Colos. It only had a couple of mana to provide, but if I tapped too much more from enervation I was likely to pass out, and it wasn’t as if I could use vitality to heal my own wounds. I was still fumbling about mentally, trying to tap the ring and cast the stupid spell when I heard heavy running footsteps thump against the solid floor of the foyer.

I looked up, thrusting my good, *or at least less crippled,* hand towards the noise, and I realized that I’d gone mostly blind. I’d lost my glasses in the fall, and with the loss of blood my vision had gone grey and shrunk down to a tiny point.

I cast Solar Pulse blindly, once, twice, three times, but didn’t hear the thud of a body hit the floor.

Instead, there was Nothus’s irritated voice, “Quinn! It’s me, sarding fext,” I felt her take me by the shoulders, propping me up as I nearly keeled over, “Oh Halaosil, you are a sarding mess. Now hold still.”

And then, the pain was gone.

The dark grey cast that my vision had taken was a little slower in receding, but at least it was clearing. I looked back down at my hands to find the left no longer charred, and the right no longer broken.

“Quinn?” Nothus asked insistently.

“Vampires,” I said, “At least four, maybe five, though I’m pretty sure I killed that one.”

I looked back up the stairs I’d fallen down, straining to listen, “I don’t know if they’re feeling like a round two,” I turned back to her, and swept a hand across the hall, “Where the hell is everyone?”

“It’s nearly midnight Quinn, everyone’s gone to bed! If I hadn’t-” she was interrupted by a screeching from up above, “Sard, I guess they’d like another shot at you.”

“Come on, away from the balcony, I don’t want one jumping down at us,” I said, as I backed towards the centre of the room, keeping Nothus behind me.

“That’s very sweet,” she said, stepping around me, “But I think that it’s probably best if I take point. You’re feeling better now Quinn, but you didn’t get much enervation back. Let me do the heavy lifting, and just focus on the ones that get behind me.”

“Alright,” I nodded, *sometimes discretion is the better part of valour and all that,* “Shouldn’t we have set off some alarms by now though? Can we expect any backup?”

She cast Apportion and a sturdy wooden chair from one tables on the wall flew towards her, “Probably not,” she said, as she caught it, “You probably set something off, assuming you killed that first one with magic, but all that’s going to do is tell whoever’s still here to hunker down. The University Guard is going to show up, but they’re not going to be here for several minutes,” she finished, as she started tearing the chair apart.

“Better than nothing I suppo-- Oh, here we go!” I shouted, as the four remaining vampires came sprinting down the hall above.

They didn’t even bother with the stairs, and instead simply threw themselves at us from the top of the wide staircase.

Nothus was ready for them, and when she threw one of her impromptu stakes, it flew with incredible accuracy to slam right through the chest of the lead vampire.

The four of them landed right in front of her, three lightly on their feet, and one in a bloody heap. Nothus roared, so loudly and deeply that I felt it resonate in my chest, and whipped another bit of chair forwards.

The vampires were fast, and this time her target managed to dodge just enough to take the projectile in the shoulder instead of the heart. The creature screeched as its shoulder was crushed by the force of the impact, but it still rushed Nothus with the rest of its kin.

Nothus seized the injured one in both hands as it leapt for her throat, all but ignoring the other two as they latched on and dug their fangs into her shoulder and side. The injured vampire struggled in her grasp and raked at her face, but Nothus was unfazed. With one of her feet she kicked at the ruins of the chair that she’d left on the floor, knocking it around until one of the wooden crossbars was left sticking straight up.

Nothus lifted the wriggling creature high over her head, and then *slammed* it down hard enough that the floor tiles cracked. The shaft was driven into its back and came out the other side in an explosion of blood and shards of bone.

I blasted the nearer of the two vampires, the one trying to bite through her side, with Solar Pulse, and it fell headless to the floor.

Nothus swatted the last of the vampires, tearing its fangs free of her shoulder, in the way that I might brush off an annoying insect, and it fell to the ground. It recovered quickly, twisting and darting to bite Nothus’s ankle, but she planted one large foot on its chest to pin it in place.

It screamed and thrashed, and tore at her leg with its fingers, but it didn’t do much. It had fangs, not claws, and Nothus had apparently taken most of my bio-engineering advice. It didn’t do much more than tear her clothing.

Nothus reached down, taking the creature’s head in both hands, and *pulled*

*OH FOR FUCKS SAKE*

The vampire’s head came free with a sickening tearing sound, and an immense amount of blood came spewing out of the vampire’s ragged stump of a neck.

Nothus dropped the head, and turned to face me. The horrified look in her eyes was all I needed to know that she sensed what I was feeling. I turned away, and sat down heavily on the ground, while I waited for the Guard to get here.

----

We were asked a great deal of questions in the hours or so that followed the fight, but I was relieved to learn that Diova’s team was safe. They too had faced an attack like mine, and while they’d had to contend with nearly twenty of the creatures, they’d been in the Patrician guild hall at the time.

“What, are vampires suicidal?” I asked, “They must have known, I mean, that place is a fortress, in the truest sense of the word.”

“They were all thralls, we only found one true vampire, and that was the one you killed upstairs,” Lili explained, “And even she was just a lieutenant, not much more than a thrall with a bit more independence.”

“So you’re telling me that there’s some vampire Big Bad Evil Guy out there that’s still got a bone to pick with me?” I asked, far too tired to rise from my seat on the floor.

She nodded, “Publishing Solar Pulse might be enough to get the Lord off your back, or they might hold a grudge. It’s hard to say.”

“Fantastic,” I sighed, “It’s probably organized enough now that a Mage would be able to learn it, even if they weren’t involved in the creation. I can give you the papers when we get back to the clubhouse. Different question, am I going to get all thrallified now?”

“Thrallified?” Lili asked, raising a delicate eyebrow.

“Turned into a thrall,” I clarified.

She shook her head, causing her gold hair to ripple and shimmer, “If it were as simple as getting bitten then there’d be more vampires than people pretty quickly. No, she’d need to kill you with her bite to turn you.”

“Well that’s some sort of consolation,” I said moving to stand, “Now let’s get the hell out of here.”

“Alright,” she said, “Do you need a hand up?”

“I’ll manage,” I said, getting unsteadily to my feet, “Just need to talk to Nothus before we leave.”

“I don’t know about that,” Lili said, tiling her head to look past me, “It looks as if she’s busy.”

I turned to see Nothus sitting at a table on the far side of the room, head propped up on one fist, and clearly quite bored. She had three guardsmen, officers I think, or the medieval equivalent to detectives, standing around her. I’d say it was an interrogation, but Nothus did not seem to be in the mood to cooperate. She just stared blankly ahead as they asked question after question.

“Why aren't they giving me a hard time?” I asked Lili quietly.

“Your robes make it quite clear that you’re not to be bothered,” she explained under her breath, “And more than that, as you might have noticed, Nothus is not well liked.”

I nodded, thinking for a moment, before striding towards the little group.

---

One of the men looked up as I approached, and held out a hand, “Excuse me your lordship, we’re not quite done here.”

“Really?” Nothus asked, “Because you slack-jawed idiots ran out of questions to ask an hour ago.”

“Perhaps if you’d cooperate-” began one of the men.

“I did sarding cooperate,” Nothus growled, obviously running out of patience, “I answered all of your questions already, twice even!”

“We just want to ensure that we have all of the facts,” explained the man who’d first spoken, “It’s very important that-”

“Alright,” I cut in, “Go away.”

“Pardon me your lordship?” The man asked.

“Go away,” I repeated, “You’re done here.”

“Excuse me your lordship but-”

“Are there any questions she hasn’t answered?” I asked, and he opened his mouth to speak, but I interrupted him again, “I don’t care if she didn’t answer them the fifth time, did she answer them the first time?”

“Yes,” Nothus growled.

The man, *detective?* sighed, “Yes.”

“Then go away. She saved my life, and now you’re giving her a hard fucking time for it,” I said tiredly, “Away away away.”

He raised his hands in surrender, and left with his subordinates in tow.

“Thanks Quinn,” Nothus said once they were out of earshot.

“You’re welcome,” I said, and then smiled, “Do I need to say it?”

She smiled as well, “No, I know it.”

I nodded, “Good.”

“And we’re...?” she asked.

“Friends?” I guessed, “Are you referring to the whole manual decapitation thing?”

“Yeah,” she nodded, grimacing a little, “Sorry about that.”

I let out a dark chuckle, “It was certainly effective. Maybe in the future though...”

“I’ll try,” she nodded, “We’re good though?”

“Yes, whatever my initial reactions were, it’s not as if what I did with Solar Pulse was much different. Though it was a lot less messy. Are you going to need somewhere safe to stay tonight?” I asked, changing the subject, “Wandering around in the middle of the night doesn’t seem like the best idea right now.”

“If I wasn’t wandering around in the middle of the night then I’d never have known that you were in trouble in the first place,” she retorted, “Besides, I can take care of myself Quinn,” she insisted, nodding towards the mess that was still being cleaned up.

“I won’t argue with that Nothus. But if you change your mind, you know where to find me. Good night.”

“Good night Quinn.”

----

Lili got me safely back to the clubhouse, though in this case the major danger came from the risk that I might pass out along the way, and not from vampires.

My clubmates were still awake when I arrived, because, of course they were. They all rushed in the moment I stepped inside, crowding around, and each of them with some salient comment to make.

“What were you doing in the Library in the middle of the night?” Kennocha hissed.

“I heard that Nothus killed a bunch of vampires, is she a slayer now? Ohmygod, ohmygod, ohmygod, do you have Buffy on your phone? She would like, totally love that,” Brandy said, jumping up and down with excitement.

“I’m glad you’re alright,” Victorina said seriously.

“We’ve got to get that Solar Pulse worked into a light enchantment,” Neferoy said gruffly, “Now that would be one fext of a talisman against more of the awful freaks.”

“Is all of that blood yours?” Minki asked, her wide eyes staring at my chest.

I looked down to see that there was really a surprising amount of dried blood caking my neck and the front of my robes.

*Fuck, I’m a mess.*

“Alright,” Halea said, “Give him some space, can’t you see that he’s even paler than usual? He’ll pass out if he doesn’t get some air. Come on now,” she continued, slipping forwards and taking my arm, “Let’s get you washed up and put to bed.”

I spared a glance for Victorina as Halea pulled me away. The two of us were well and truly done with each other, and it had been a month, but I couldn’t help but consider how she might be hurt by this. She met my gaze as I looked back and gave me a small sad smile, and a tilt of the head.

*So that’s what that’s like.*



# Chapter 70

**Quinn**

---

*Ohhh... oh my, now this is one hell of a way to wake up.*

I lifted my head up slightly to see that, yes, there was a roughly Halea sized lump moving around under the covers. My head fell fell back to the pillow, and I let out a long sigh. It was very quiet in my bedroom, the only noise being the soft, wet, sounds that escaped from underneath the sheets. I was dimly aware that it was late in the morning, or maybe early afternoon, but I tried to avoid thinking too much, and just let myself relax.

Halea was clearly quite good at what she was doing, which I did not at all consider a bad thing, and was able to draw things out for ages, until I finally couldn’t take it anymore. She poked her head out from underneath the covers a minute or so later, after more soft, wet, sounds.

“Feeling better?” she teased, as she tucked herself in under my arm.

“Yeah,” I muttered lethargically.

“Hey!” she said, slapping my side, “Don’t you fall back to sleep, it’s nearly noon. Especially not after I went to all that trouble to wake you up.”

“Is that what you were doing?” I laughed, a little more clear headed.

“Yes,” she said primly.

“Well, I’m certainly not going to complain.”

“So,” she said in a dusky voice, “You’d want more then?”

“What, now?” I asked incredulously.

“I thought humans were supposed to have incredible endurance, are you telling me that’s not true?” she teased.

“Well half an hour of your nibbling has left me just a little bit tender down there.”

“I’m only teasing,” she admitted, “No, I was thinking about later.”

“Oh?”

“Mmm hmm, after all, you do need some help with battle magic, at least if last night was any indication.”

“Where exactly is this going?” I asked, looking at her out of the corner of my eye.

“It could be a little competition. I tutor you, we spar a little, and each time you win...” she trailed off, tracing her fingers down my abdomen.

“That’s an interesting sort of incentive system you’re setting up there.”

“However, if *I* win,” she whispered, reaching up and taking a firm hold of my hair, “Well,” she grinned, “You get the idea.”

“Now that hardly seems fair,” I protested, “I won’t even have a chance. This sounds like a not so complicated ploy to get me down on my knees.”

“And?”

“Now I’m not afraid of a little reciprocation,” I told her, “But I’ve got to have a fighting chance at least.”

“Oh fine,” she said petulantly, “I’ll come up with something else. But whatever it is, you can bet that there’s going to be a whole bunch of oral sarding going on.”

----

I had a few days to rest after my encounter with the vampires, and spent most of the time relaxing and sorting out my mana problems.

Nothus had been onto something when she’d mentioned elf sacrifice, but not in the way that either of us had thought.

No, I wasn’t about to go around killing people to supply the mana I’d need, but it had given me an idea. Rather than sacrifice a person, I’d come up with the idea of sacrificing an animal instead. Maybe a lot of animals. I wasn’t going to get soul from anything non-sentient, but the vitality could add up pretty quickly. I’d even recovered a book on blood magic from the Forbidden Tower that I’d be able to refer to. ‘The Qualities of Bloodstone’ had been part of the Necromancy collection I’d copied down, and I recalled from my brief flip through it that it had referred to spells such as Drain Vitality and Drain Enervation.

Unfortunately, it didn’t quite hold the answers that I wanted. Animal sacrifice was certainly a solution, but not a very effective one. An animal as large as an ox for example would have as much as *three hundred* total energy when you accounted for both vitality and enervation, and while that sounded like exactly the answer I was looking for, I was disappointed upon reading further.

With the notable exception of spells that had an affinity to specific animals, a caster would rarely get more than a fraction of the animal’s total enervation and vitality. In my case, that fraction was likely one in fifty.

*Which makes sense, I guess. Otherwise cattle farmers would be making bank by selling their herds to the University.*

The book did hold the answers that I *needed* though, at least, for some definitions of ‘need.’ The solution of course was the titular ‘Bloodstone’. It was like a manastone, but rather than draw from ambient mana to recharge itself, the bloodstone was filled by making living sacrifices. It wasn’t even that hard to make one, just a drop of the enchanter’s blood and the life of a goat, lamb, or stag.

*And no capacity limit either. Damn.*

Once made, it was just one big battery for naughty magic. Theoretically, the bloodstone could save me from the logistical nightmare that would be the simultaneous sacrifice of the fifty oxen it would take to make the spellstone. I could do it one by one, charging as I went, but that was not what caught my eye. What caught my eye was the passage that mentioned that the ‘sacrifice’ need not necessarily die in the process of charging the bloodstone.

To feed vitality into the stone, I would need to kill whatever I was sacrificing, but not in the case of soul.

*And again I come back to soul.*

I’d known from the very beginning that soul was an option, but had been reluctant to do if for one simple reason. The spell stone was three hundred mana, and I had to work in units of a thousand. I could burn a year of my life to make the spellstone, but then that extra seven hundred mana would be wasted.

*With the bloodstone though...*

It wouldn’t be hard either, in fact, it was no different than when I’d opened myself up to Nothus for her to heal Minki. No complex ritual, no big mess, just a thought and the stone would be charged.

*Can I afford to lose another year? I think so. I’m functionally immortal, so it’s not like I’m going to lose soul any other way than spending it like this. Yeah, especially if I’ll still have the other seven hundred to spend later, I think this makes it worth the price.*

Next Fextday, a week from today, I’d go out early in the morning. I’d track down a stag somewhere in my future demesne, hogtie it with Apportation, and then sacrifice the thing. I’d be able to burn away any evidence of the blood magic, and bury or dump the body. Get back to the clubhouse, make the spellstone, and then head back to the guildhall. If all went according to plan, I might even be able to do the whole thing that same day, assuming I could find a stag without too much trouble.

*After all, what could possibly go wrong?*

---

I was given the chance on the following Louday morning to sign up for the team sparring matches in the Arena with the rest of my class, and did so. I’d originally planned to skip it, mostly because I thought that I hadn’t needed the practice, but my encounter with the vampires had been proof that I’d been mistaken. That ambush, a couple months ago now, had inflated my ego a little. I’d thought at the time that it had been a pretty good indication of how far my abilities had come, but that had been foolish of me. The vampire hadn’t even used any magic, aside from maybe a little light compulsion, and she was still more than capable of killing me.

I’d gotten out of that alive only through sheer luck, and with Nothus’s help. I did not intend for that to happen again.

Of course, I was selected to lead one of the four teams. Was it because I had some special insight into leading mages into battle? Was it in deference to that ambush I’d fought off with Victorina? No, of course not. It was because I’d convinced everyone that I had imperial blood.

The selection method the professor used was only made more clear when I considered the other teams. The other three team captains weren’t Imperial or Royal, but that was only because we had no other Imperial or Royal students in the class. Instead, two were Duke’s sons, and one was the son of a Marquis. Were there more skilled Mages, or more tactically minded leaders? Oh, probably, but silly things like merit didn’t matter.

“Quinn, in deference to your rank, you’ll be allowed to make the first choice of teammates,” the professor said, and I was reminded of the way that teams were picked for sports in highschool, “It’ll be teams of four, including yourself, so choose accordingly.”

“Four?” I asked, “Shouldn’t it be closer to six? We’ve got about twenty four students now that the other three classes have joined us.”

One of the ducal heirs, whose name I still hadn’t wasted the time to learn, piped up, “I would have thought that after all that time spent under Victorina’s heel, you might appreciate the chance to make your own choices,” he shook his head with exaggerated sadness, “I guess we know now why it is human woman are so used to wearing trousers.”

“I take it from your *incredibly* insightful remark, that the women aren't usually invited?” I asked, turning to look at the short pudgy Mage in shimmering gold robes.

“No, why, you want some skirts to hide behind?” he replied.

“Oh go sard yourself Olar,” one of the girls shouted from the back.

“That one!” I said pointing in the general direction of the shout, “She’s my first pick for my team.”

Olar opened his mouth, likely to say something offensive, but he was cut off by the professor, “Alright, that’s enough. And Quinn,” he said, looking to me, “You can’t force anyone to join your team, and I just want you to be aware that selecting Isal for your team might limit who else is willing to join.”

I didn’t respond, and instead took a moment to consider my classmates, looking at each one in turn. I won’t pretend that I terrified them with my intense stare, causing them to avert their eyes in terror, but more than a few of my classmates seemed a little nervous. Granted, about twice as many were looking at me with naked contempt, but they could get fucked. There was one face that stood out in the crowd though, and it took a monumental effort not to jump up in my seat when I noticed her.

Sila was sitting near the back of the classroom by the door, she’d evidently come in with one of the other classes, and she positively lit up the moment she saw me looking at her.

*Five women, not even half of one class, let alone four classes, but they’re the ones who bothered to show up. Even if one of them is Sila, they’re either damn good, or damn stubborn. Yeah, I think I can do this.*

“Don’t care, go ahead and make your pick Olar.”

----

We were dismissed from class early so that each of us had time to hash things out with our new team mates. Make introductions, talk tactics, and the like. In the interests of finding somewhere quiet to talk, and also because I hadn’t eaten yet today, I took my new team of followers out for a late brunch at the usual cafe.

This was quite a step up in the world for most of the team, since only Isal had been born into any particular privilege. The rest, Nina, Setisi, Myli, and Sila, were all women of low birth. In fact, as the daughter of a tavern owner, Sila might have been somewhere above average in our little group.

Isal, a rather pretty blonde city elf, was the daughter of a Count and wore the crimson robes to match. Her sharp features, small mouth, and generally sour expression did make her seem perpetually angry, but she was pleasant despite the initial impression.

*And she told off Olar, which is a big plus.*

Setisi was likely the most interesting one of the group, and was one of the few gnomes I’d had the pleasure of meeting so far. She shared Djeta’s reddish brown colouring, and I was reminded again of the colour of the soil on Prince Edward Island. Her hair too was red, or rather, orange, and was cut quite short.

*Pixie cut? Or I guess, this is a gnome cut?*

Nina and Myli were also city elves, but not ones of great means, as far as I could tell. They had their bursaries, or at least I was pretty sure they did, but seemed to follow Sila’s initial strategy of thriftiness. They both spent the money on well cut robes of quality cloth, but had not wasted a single drachm on any flash or fancy dyes.

And then there was Sila, who was so excited that she looked like she was about to burst. I’d been half expecting her to faint the moment I called her name to join my team, and if she’d been standing at the time, she might very well have done so.

She’d clearly had some work done, but thankfully she’d not taken it as far as Diova had with Mata. The changes were subtle, but noticeable. Her smile, previously crooked and slightly off-white was now perfect and pearly white. Her hair, which had always been in fairly good shape for a village girl, was now perfect. It had a healthy luster to it, and the odd split end had been touched up. Her skin which had always been a little rough and weather-worn, particularly around the hands, was now flawless, and a great deal more pale. Oh, and now she had breasts. Not too huge, she was still plausibly proportioned for a sixteen or seventeen year old elf, but the increase had been more than puberty would be able to account for.

*At least she hasn’t thrown herself at me yet. But the second we’re alone...*

“Are we supposed to come up with a team name?” Nina asked a little tentatively, as she looked between Isal and myself.

“And a colour,” Isal nodded.

“We could do blue!” Sila said, positively bubbling, “Quinn really likes blue.”

Isal raised an eyebrow, “You two know each other?”

“Yes,” Sila said cheerfully.

”Kinda,” I said, less cheerfully, at the same time.

Isal’s eyebrow somehow managed to creep further up her forehead, but did not comment, “Blue then?” she asked.

This was followed by a round of nods from the other women at the table, but I shook my head, “I had something different in mind. Olar and the others are already going to be giving us a hard time since I put together a team of girls, and I think we should play to that.”

“What, pick something that seems more manly?” Isal asked.

“No,” I grinned, “Very much the opposite.”

“Pink!” she declared.

“As bright a pink as is possible,” I agreed, “We shall strain the limits of elven technology to find a pink that is girly enough.”

“And you’re okay with that?” Isal asked, “I mean, you’re going to be wearing the uniform too, you’re not concerned that Olar is going to make some remark about your, um, preferences?”

“Preferences? He’s the one that’s terrified at the thought of a woman coming within ten feet of his little testosterone party. Whose preferences are in doubt here exactly?”

Isal smirked, “That’s a good point I suppose. What about a team name then?” Isal asked, “Do we also want something suitably ‘girly’?”

“Super happy flower party!” Myli cheered, and judging from her voice, I was pretty sure that she was at least a couple years younger than Sila.

I shrugged and glanced at Isal, who just shook her head and laughed.

“Alright,” I said, “Super happy flower party it is. Now, let’s talk a bit about tactics.”

---

The group split up a couple hours later, after we’d sorted out some basic tactical doctrine, and gotten an idea of what each of us was able to do.

Sila, of course, followed about a step behind as I left the cafe.

“Do you want to go somewhere to sit down Quinn?” Sila asked.

“We were just sitting down in the cafe back there,” I pointed out obtusely.

“I know,” Sila said softly, “But there was everyone else there with us.”

“Sila...” I began.

She grabbed my arm roughly, pulling me around to face her, and I was reminded then of how much stronger elves tended to be. She clenched her jaw, and met my gaze with an angry expression in her eyes.

“We *need* to talk,” she demanded, “You can’t just keep running away from everything.”

“Let go of my arm,” I commanded, without raising my voice.

She did, pulling her hand away as if she’d just been burned, but her steady gaze did not waver.

“Come on,” I said finally, “I was going to the Library anyway.”

---

I found a quiet place, much like the little alcove I’d been working in before I was ambushed by the vampire, though this one had a window in the exterior wall. I sat down, the cold sunlight of mid-autumn streaming through the window to light the room, and indicated the chair across from me.

“What is it Sila?” I asked, as she made herself comfortable.

“Just a moment,” she said, before taking something out of her belt. A belt actually, that was identical to mine. It was a short wand, about a foot long, and she waved it about the small alcove and across the two of us before finally putting it back into it’s pouch.

“Alright,” she said finally, “It’s safe, she’s not listening.”

I raised an eyebrow at that, “Who?”

“Victorina,” she said through gritted teeth, leaning forwards, “I think I can get you away from her.”

“Sila,” I sighed, “I don’t need-”

“She raped you,” she hissed, totally derailing my train of thought, “She raped you, she’s a rapist, and if she doesn’t let you go, I’m going to kill her.”

*You know, I thought that this whole conversation was going to be a mess. But this is something else entirely.*

“Sila, I understand why you might take issue with Victorina and I sleeping together, but that’s my choice to make,” I told her, “And I did make that choice, Victorina didn’t force anything on me.”

“You don’t need to pretend with me Quinn,” Sila said pleadingly, “Not everyone can be strong all the time. I saw Quinn, you don’t need to pretend, I even tried to help then, but... I just wasn’t ready.”

“You saw?” I asked flatly, “So that night someone took a shot at Victorina and I-”

“Just Victorina,” Sila said, slamming her fist down on the arm of the chair, “I saw what she was doing to you, and you were all tied up, oh gods,” she quavered, “And I couldn’t stop her, not for good,” then her voice grew stronger, “But I can now. You don’t need to do anything Quinn,” she promised, “Just come away with me. I have a big place out in the countryside, just come away with me. You’ll be safe there while I deal with her. Please,” she pleaded, “You don’t need to let her hurt you.”

*For fuck’s sake, how am I supposed to explain some light kinky fun to an innocent little village girl?*

“I swear Quinn,” she promised, after I’d been quiet for a moment, still trying to figure out what the hell to say, “I’ll protect you. Just tonight, you come and stay with me, instead of going back to her.”

“I don’t ‘go back to her’,” I said finally, “Not any more. We broke up, nearly a month ago now.”

“That’s great!” Sila said, hopping up to a crouch in her chair, “Now just-”

“And whatever you might have seen, it obviously wasn’t what you thought it was. The how and why of us separating isn’t important, but what is important, is that Victorina and I are still friends. And if you try to kill my friend,” I said through gritted teeth, “You had better be ready for the fucking consequences.”

Sila went a little pale, and leaned back in her chair, “I’m sorry Quinn,” she whispered, “But what I saw-”

“Sometimes,” I said tiredly, “I’m *in charge*, and sometimes she gets to be *in charge.* That time, she was *in charge.*”

“So, she didn’t...”

“No,” I said simply.

“And, you wanted her to do it?” she asked.

“Yes,” I nodded.

And then she started crying.

---

I got to my spell invention class a little late, extricating myself from the mess with Sila had taken longer than I’d realized, and I’d gone for a bit of a walk afterwards to clear my head.

*She’s cute, especially now, and I enjoy her company. If she were a year or two older I’d be happy to have the same sort of friends with benefits arrangement with her, as I do with Halea. But even if she was a couple years older, I was pretty sure that she wasn’t going to settle for that. She wanted more, and if I only gave her what I was willing to and then not one thing further, she’d be left feeling used.*

“Quinn, you’re looking well for someone who was nearly eaten by a vampire,” Diova said, as I sat down heavily across from him.

I shrugged, “Been eating a lot of red meat, I’ll be back at full strength in a few more days.”

“Red meat?” He asked.

“For the iron, to replace all the blood I lost. Nothus didn’t have the mana to create five or six more pints of blood, so I’ve got to put it all back the hard way.”

“There is iron in red meat?” Baron Bronippo asked.

“And it helps create blood?” Tosa wondered.

“Maybe elves are different,” I said, trying to change the subject, explaining what hemoglobin were and how they worked would take all day, “How are we on Solar Pulse?”

“All but done,” Diova explained, “With you present we’ll have it done today, tomorrow at the latest.”

“Good, hopefully once we’ve got everything sorted and people start learning it vampires will be discouraged from doing any more evil shit anywhere near the University,” I said tiredly.
